name: Proposition logic
statement:
\[\textrm{Alphabet } \mathcal{L} = \left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\textbf{variables}: & p_0,p_1,p_2,... \\
\textbf{unary connective}: & \lnot \\
\textbf{binary connectives}: & \land, \lor, \rightarrow, \leftrightarrow \\
\textbf{punctuation}: & (,\ ) 
\end{array}\right.\]
\\
A string is a finite sequence of characters from the alphabet. The length of a string is the number of symbols used in it.
\\\\
Formulas are built using the following rules:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Every proposition variable is a formula
\item If $A$ is a formula then $\lnot A$ is a formula
\item If $A$ and $B$ are formulas then $(A\star B)$ is a formula for $\star\in\{\land,\lor,\rightarrow,\leftrightarrow\}$
\end{enumerate}

A string is a formula if it can be built using a finite number of application of the above formation rules.

name: First symbol of a formula
statement: If $\phi$ is a formula then either $\phi$ is a proposition variable of the first symbol is one of $\lnot$ and $($

proofs.text:
By Induction on the length $n$ of $\phi$:
\begin{itemize}
\item case $n=1$, then $\phi$ must be a proposition variable
\item using strong induction on formulas of all lengths $\leq n$, let $\phi$ be a formula of length $n+1$\\
$\Rightarrow$ $\phi$ is not a propositional variable as $n+1>1$\\
$\Rightarrow$ either $\phi=\lnot\psi$ or $\phi=(\psi_1\star\psi_2)$ for some formulas $\psi_1,\psi_2$ and some binary connective $\star$\\
$\Rightarrow$ first symbol of $\phi$ is $\lnot$ or $($
\end{itemize}

name: Unique readability theorem
statement:
For each formula $\phi$ exactly one of the following folds:
By Induction on the length $n$ of $\phi$:
\begin{itemize}
\item $\phi$ is $p_i$ for some unique $i\in\mathbb N$
\item $\phi$ is $\lnot\psi$ for some unique formula $\psi$
\item $\phi$ is $(\psi\star\chi)$ for some unique formulas $\psi,\chi$ and\\ some unique binary connective $\star\in\{\land,\lor,\rightarrow,\leftrightarrow\}$
\end{itemize}

name: Valuation
Satisfiable / Tautology
statement:
Say a valuation $\tilde{v}$ satisfies a formula $\phi$ if $\tilde{v}(\phi)=T$\\\\
If a formula is satisfies by some valuation then call it satisfiable.\\\\
If a formula $\phi$ is satisfied by all valuations then call it a tautology and write $\models\phi$.

name: Logical consequence / Logically equivalent
statement:
If $\phi,\psi$ are formulas such that for all valuations $v$, $\tilde{v}(\psi)\Rightarrow\tilde{v}(\phi)$, then write $\psi\models\phi$ and say that $\phi$ is a logical consequence of $\psi$.\\
\\
If $\Gamma$ is a set of formulas and if $\phi$ is a formula, then $\phi$ is a logical consequence of $\Gamma$ and write $\Gamma\models\phi$ if for all valuations $v$, $(\forall\psi\in\Gamma, \tilde{v}(\psi)=T)\Rightarrow\tilde{v}(\phi)=T$.\\
\\
Say two formulas $\phi,\psi$ are logically equivalent if $\phi\models\psi$ and $\psi\models\phi$, written $\phi\equiv\psi$.

name: Logical consequence criterion
statement: $\psi\models\phi$ iff $\models(\psi\rightarrow\phi)$

name: Consequence of a set
statement: $\Gamma\cup\{\psi\}\models\psi$ iff $\Gamma\models(\psi\rightarrow\phi)$

name: Logical equivalence criterion
statement: $\phi\equiv\psi$ iff $\models(\phi\leftrightarrow\psi)$

name: And / Or equivalence
statement: $(\phi\lor\psi)\equiv\lnot(\lnot\phi\land\lnot\psi)$

proofs.text:
\[\begin{array}{rll}
             & \tilde{v}(\lnot(\lnot\phi\land\lnot\psi))=F & \\
\text{iff} & \tilde{v}(\lnot\phi\land\lnot\psi)=T & \text{by }tt\lnot \\
\text{iff} & \tilde{v}(\lnot\phi)=\tilde{v}(\lnot\psi)=T & \text{by }tt\land \\
\text{iff} & \tilde{v}(\phi)=\tilde{v}(\psi)=F & \text{by }tt\lnot \\
\text{iff} & \tilde{v}(\phi\lor\psi)=F & \text{by }tt\lor \\
\end{array}\]

name: Truth function
statement:
We denote by $V_n$ the set of all valuations of the first $n$ propositional variables.\\
\\
An $n$-ary truth function is a function $J:V_n\rightarrow\{T,F\}$. Hence there are precisely $2^n$ $n$-ary truth functions for each $n$.\\
\\
Of a formula $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L)$ contains only propositional variables from the set $\{p_0,...,p_{n-1}\}$, write $\phi\in Form_n(\mathcal L)$. Then $\phi$ generates a unique $n$-ary truth function $J_\phi:V_n\rightarrow\{T,F\}$ s.t. $J_\phi(v)=\tilde{v}(\phi)$.

name: A truth function uniquely identifies a formula
statement: For every $n$-ary truth function $J:V_n\rightarrow\{T,F\}$, there is some $\phi\in Form_n(\mathcal L)$ s.t. $J_\phi=J$.

proofs.text:
Let $J:V_n\rightarrow\{T,F\}$ be any $n$-ary truth function.\\
\\
If $J(v)=F$ for all $v\in V_n$, take $\phi=(p_0\land\lnot p_0)$ for example, then $J=J_\phi$.\\
Otherwise let $U=\{v\in V_n:J(v)=T\}\neq\phi$. For each $v\in U$ and each $i<n$ define the formula
$$\psi_i^v=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}p_i&\text{if }v(p_i)=T\\\lnot p_i&\text{if }v(p_i)=F\end{array}\right.$$
and let $\psi^v=\bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1}\psi_i^v$\\
\\
Then for any valuation $w\in V_n$ one has the following equivalence $(\star)$,
$$\begin{array}{llll}
\tilde{w}(\psi^v)=T & \text{iff}  & \forall i<n,\ \tilde{w}(\psi_i^v)=T & \text{by tt }\land \\
& \text{iff} & w=v
\end{array}$$
Now define $phi=\bigvee_{v\in U}\psi^v$\\
\\
Then for any $w\in V_n$,
$$\begin{array}{llll}
\tilde{w}(\phi)=T & \text{iff} & \exists v\in U\ s.t.\ \tilde{w}(\psi^v)=T & \text{by tt }\lor \\
& \text{iff} & \exists v\in V\ s.t.\ w=v & \text{by }(\star) \\
& \text{iff} & w\in U \\
& \text{iff}  & J(w)=T
\end{array}$$
Hence $\forall w\in V_n,\ J_\phi(w)=J(w)$, so $J_\phi=J$.

name: Normal forms
statement:
A formula $\phi$ is in DNF (Disjunctive Normal Form) if it has the form $\phi=\bigvee_{i=1}^m\bigwedge_{j=1}^n\psi_{ij}$ where each $\psi_{ij}$ is either a propositional variable or the negation of one.\\
\\
CNF (Conjunctive Normal Form) looks like $\phi=\bigwedge_{i=1}^m\bigvee{j=1}^n\psi_{ij}$

name: Any formula is equivalent to one in CNF and one in DNF
statement: For any formula $\phi$, there exist formulas $\psi$ in CNF and $\chi$ in DNF such that $\phi\equiv\psi\equiv\chi$.

name: Language of a set of connectives
statement: Suppose $S$ is a set of truth-functional connectives, ie: they are defined by truth tables. Write $\mathcal{L}[S]$ to be the language of these connectives and define $Form(\mathcal{L}[S])$ accordingly.

name: Adequate
statement:
A language $\mathcal{L}[S]$ is called adequate (or truth functionally complete) if it can generate any formula (up to logical equivalence).\\
\\
So $\forall J:V_n\rightarrow\{T,F\},\ \exists\phi\in Form_n(\mathcal{L}[S])\ s.t.\ J_\phi=J$

name: Common adequate languages
statement:
$S=\{\lnot,\lor,\land\}$ is adequate.\\
$S=\{\lnot,\lor\}$ is adequate.\\
$S=\{\lnot,\land\}$ is adequate.\\
$S=\{\lnot,\rightarrow\}$ is adequate.\\
$S=\{\lor,\land,\rightarrow\}$ is not adequate as $\lnot p_0$ is not representable.\\
\\
There are precisely two connectives $\uparrow$ and $\downarrow$ such that $S=\{\uparrow\}$ and $S=\{\downarrow\}$ are adequate.

name: Formal proof
Any formula implies itself
statement: $\vdash(\phi\rightarrow\phi)$

proofs.text:
$\begin{array}{ll}
\alpha_1=(\phi\rightarrow(\phi\rightarrow\phi)) & (\text{A1 with } \alpha=\phi,\ \beta=\phi) \\
\alpha_2=(\phi\rightarrow((\phi\rightarrow\phi)\rightarrow\phi) & (\text{A1 with } \alpha=\phi,\ \beta=(\phi\rightarrow\phi)) \\
\alpha_3=((\phi\rightarrow((\phi\rightarrow\phi)\rightarrow\phi))\rightarrow((\phi\rightarrow(\phi\rightarrow\phi))\rightarrow(\phi\rightarrow\phi))) & (\text{A2 with } \alpha=\phi,\ \beta=(\phi\rightarrow\phi),\ \gamma=\phi) \\
\alpha_4=((\phi\rightarrow(\phi\rightarrow\phi))\rightarrow(\phi\rightarrow\phi)) & (\text{MP with } \alpha_2,\ \alpha_3) \\
\alpha_5=(\phi\rightarrow\phi) & (\text{MP with } \alpha_1,\ \alpha_4)
\end{array}$

name: A contradiction proves anything
statement: $\forall\phi,\psi\in Form(\mathcal L_0),\ \{\phi,\lnot\phi\}\vdash\psi$

proofs.text:
$\begin{array}{ll}
\alpha_1=(\lnot\phi\rightarrow(\lnot\psi\rightarrow\lnot\phi)) & \text{A1 with }\alpha=\lnot\phi,\ \beta=\lnot\psi\\
\alpha_2=\lnot\phi & \in\Gamma\\
\alpha_3=(\lnot\psi\rightarrow\lnot\phi) & \text{MP with }\alpha_1,\ \alpha_2\\
\alpha_4=((\lnot\psi\rightarrow\lnot\phi)\rightarrow(\phi\rightarrow\psi)) & \text{A3 with }\alpha=\phi,\ \beta=\psi\\
\alpha_5=(\phi\rightarrow\phi) & \text{MP with }\alpha_3,\ \alpha_4\\
\alpha_6=\phi & \in\Gamma\\
\alpha_7=\psi & \text{MP with }\alpha_5,\ \alpha_6
\end{array}$

name: Sound
statement: A system is sound if everything that is provable is true.

name: The standard language is sound
statement: $L_0$ is sound. So for any $\Gamma\subset Form(\mathcal L_0)$ and any $\alpha\in Form(\mathcal L_0)$, if $\Gamma\vdash\alpha$ then $\Gamma\models\alpha$

name: Deduction theorem
statement: For any $\Gamma\in Form(\mathcal L_0)$ and any $\alpha,\beta\in Form(\mathcal L_0)$, if $\Gamma\cup\{\alpha\}\vdash\beta$ then $\Gamma\vdash(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)$

proofs.text:
We prove by induction on $m$, if $\alpha_1,...,\alpha_m$ is derivable in $\mathcal L_0$ from the hypothesis $\Gamma\cup\{\alpha\}$, then for all $i\leq m$, $(\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_i)$ is derivable from $\Gamma$.
\\
\begin{description}
\item[(m=1)] There are three cases, if $\alpha_1$ is an axiom then $\vdash\alpha_1$, if $\alpha_1=\alpha$ then $\vdash(\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_1)$,\\
else $\alpha_1\in\Gamma$ in which case
\[\begin{array}{rll}
1) & \alpha_1 & (\in\Gamma) \\
2) & (\alpha_1\rightarrow(\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_1)) & (\text{A1}) \\
3) & (\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_1) & (\text{MP }1,\ 2)
\end{array}\]
Then noting that if $A\subset B$ and $A\vdash\phi$ then $B\vdash\phi$, we have $\Gamma\vdash(\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_1)$.
\item[(m+1)] Suppose the result is true for derivations of length $\leq m$ and let $\alpha_1,...,\alpha_{m+1}$ be a derivation in $\mathcal L_0$ from $\Gamma\cup\{\alpha\}$.\\
Then if $\alpha_{m+1}$ is an axiom or $\alpha_{m+1}\in\Gamma\cup\{\alpha\}$ then proceed as in the base case, else $\alpha_{m+1}$ is obtained by MP from some earlier $\alpha_j,\alpha_k$, so $\alpha_j=(\alpha_k\rightarrow\alpha_{m+1})$. By the inductive hypothesis we have that $\Gamma\vdash(\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_k)$ and $\Gamma\vdash(\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_j)$, so $\Gamma\vdash(\alpha\rightarrow(\alpha_k\rightarrow\alpha_{m+1}))$
\vspace{5mm}\\
Let $\beta_1,...,\beta_r$ be a derivation in $\mathcal L_0$ of $(\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_k)=\beta_r$ from $\Gamma$.\\
Let $\gamma_1,...,\gamma_s$ be a derivation in $\mathcal L_0$ of $(\alpha\rightarrow(\alpha_k\rightarrow\alpha_{m+1}))=\gamma_s$ from $\Gamma$.
\vspace{5mm}\\
Then
\[\begin{array}{rll}
1 & \beta_1 \\
... & ... \\
r-1 & \beta_{r-1} \\
r & (\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_k) \\
r+1 & \gamma_1 \\
... & ... \\
r+s-1 & \gamma_{s-1} \\
r+s & (\alpha\rightarrow(\alpha_k\rightarrow\alpha_{m+1})) \\
r+s+1 & ((\alpha\rightarrow(\alpha_k\rightarrow\alpha_{m+1}))\rightarrow((\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_k)\rightarrow(\alpha_k\rightarrow\alpha_{m+1}))) & (\text{A2}) \\
r+s+2 & ((\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_k)\rightarrow(\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_{m+1})) & (\text{MP }r+s,\ r+s+1) \\
r+s+3 & (\alpha\rightarrow\alpha_{m+1}) & (\text{MP }r,\ r+s+2)
\end{array}\]
\end{description}

name: Transitivity
statement: If $\Gamma\vdash(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)$ and $\Gamma\vdash(\beta\rightarrow\gamma)$ then $\Gamma\vdash(\alpha\rightarrow\gamma)$

proofs.text:
By the Deduction theorem it suffices to show that $\Gamma\cup\{\alpha\}\vdash\gamma$
\[\begin{array}{rll}
... & ... & \text{Proof from }\Gamma \\
r & (\alpha\rightarrow\beta) \\
... & ... & \text{Proof from }\Gamma \\
r+s & (\beta\rightarrow\gamma) \\
r+s+1 & \alpha & (\in\Gamma\cup\{\alpha\}) \\
r+s+2 & \beta & (\text{MP }r,\ r+s+1) \\
r+s+3 & \gamma & (\text{MP }r+s,\ r+s+2)
\end{array}\]

name: Sequent calculus
statement:
The sequent calculus $SQ$ is the system where a proof of $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L_0)$ from $\Gamma\subset Form(\mathcal L_0)$ is a finite sequence of sequents, ie: $\Delta\vdash_{SQ}\psi$ with $\Gamma\vdash_{SQ}\phi$ as the last step.
\\
Sequents may be formed according to the following rules:
\begin{description}
\item[Ass: ] If $\psi\in\Delta$ then infer $\Delta\vdash_{SQ}\psi$
\item[MP: ] From $\Delta\vdash_{SQ}\psi$ and $\Delta'\vdash_{SQ}(\psi\rightarrow\chi)$ infer $\Delta\cup\Delta'\vdash_{SQ}\chi$
\item[DT: ] From $\Delta\cup\{\psi\}\vdash_{SQ}\chi$ infer $\Delta\vdash_{SQ}(\psi\rightarrow\chi)$
\item[PC: ] From $\Delta\cup\{\lnot\psi\}\vdash_{SQ}\chi$ and $\Delta'\cup\{\lnot\psi\}\vdash_{SQ}\lnot\chi$ infer $\Delta\cup\Delta'\vdash_{SQ}\psi$
\end{description}

name: Axiom A3 in sequent calculus
statement: $((\lnot\beta\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)\rightarrow(\alpha\rightarrow\beta))$

proofs.text:
\[\begin{array}{rll}
1) & \lnot\beta\vdash\lnot\beta & [\text{Ass}] \\
2) & (\lnot\beta\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)\vdash(\lnot\beta\rightarrow\lnot\alpha) & [\text{Ass}] \\
3) & (\lnot\beta\rightarrow\lnot\alpha),\lnot\beta\vdash\lnot\alpha & [\text{MP }1,\ 2] \\
4) & \alpha,\lnot\beta\vdash\alpha & [\text{Ass}] \\
5) & (\lnot\beta\rightarrow\lnot\alpha),\alpha\vdash\beta & [\text{PC }3,\ 4] \\
6) & (\lnot\beta\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)\vdash(\alpha\rightarrow\beta) & [\text{DT }5] \\
7) & \vdash((\lnot\beta\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)\rightarrow(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)) & [\text{DT }6] \\
\end{array}\]

name: A standard formal proof and sequent calculus are equivalent
statement: $\mathcal L_0$ and $SQ$ are equivalent, that is for all $\Gamma,\phi$ we have $\Gamma\vdash_{\mathcal L_0}\phi\Leftrightarrow\Gamma\vdash_{SQ}\phi$

name: Consistent
statement: Let $\Gamma\in Form(\mathcal L_0)$, $\Gamma$ is said to be consistent if for no formula $\alpha$ both $\Gamma\vdash\alpha$ and $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\alpha$.

name: Consistent criterion
statement: $\Gamma\cup\{\phi\}$ is inconsistent iff $\Gamma\vdash\phi$

name: Extend a consistent set
statement: Suppose $\Gamma$ is consistent and $\Gamma\vdash\phi$, then $\Gamma\cup\{\phi\}$ is consistent.

proofs.text:
Suppose not, then for some $\alpha$,
$$\left.\begin{array}{l}\Gamma\cup\{\lnot\phi\}\vdash\alpha\\\Gamma\cup\{\lnot\phi\}\vdash\lnot\alpha\end{array}\right\}\Rightarrow_{DT}\left.\begin{array}{l}\Gamma\vdash(\phi\rightarrow\alpha)\\\Gamma\vdash(\phi\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)\end{array}\right\}\Rightarrow_{\text{MP }\Gamma\vdash\phi}\begin{array}{l}\Gamma\vdash\alpha\\\Gamma\vdash\lnot\alpha\end{array}$$
which is a contradiction as $\Gamma$ is consistent.

name: Maximally consistent
Maximal consistency criterion
statement: $\Gamma$ is maximally consistent iff for all $\phi,\ \Gamma\cup\{\phi\}$ is consistent $\Rightarrow\Gamma\vdash\phi$

name: Maximal consistency properties
Maximally consistent implies satisfiable
statement: Suppose $\Gamma$ is maximally consistent, then $\Gamma$ is satisfiable.

name: Maximally consistent supserset
statement: Suppose $\Gamma$ is consistent, then there is a maximally consistent $\Gamma'$ s.t. $\Gamma\subset\Gamma'$

proofs.text:
Note $Form(\mathcal L_0)$ is countable, say that $Form(\mathcal L_0)=\{\phi_1,\phi_2,\phi_3,...\}$.\\
Construct consistent sets $\Gamma_0\subset\Gamma_1\subset\Gamma_2\subset...$ as follows,
\begin{itemize}
\item $\Gamma_0=\Gamma$
\item Having constructed $\Gamma_0,...,\Gamma_n$, let $\Gamma_{n+1}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\Gamma_n\cup\{\phi_{n+1}\}&\text{if }\Gamma_n\vdash\phi_{n+1}\\\Gamma_n\cup\{\lnot\phi_{n+1}\}&\text{if }\Gamma_n\nvdash\phi_{n+1}\end{array}\right.$\\
then $\Gamma_{n+1}$ is consistent by previous propositions.
\end{itemize}
Let $\Gamma'=\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty\Gamma_n$. Any proof of $\Gamma'\vdash\alpha$ and $\Gamma'\vdash\lnot\alpha$ would use only finitely many formulas from $\Gamma'$, so for some $n$, $\Gamma_n\vdash\alpha$ and $\Gamma_n\vdash\lnot\alpha$, contradicting consistency of $\Gamma_n$. Hence $\Gamma'$ is consistent.\\
\\
Finally, $\Gamma'$ is maximal as for all $n$ either $\phi_n\in\Gamma'$ or $\lnot\phi_n\in\Gamma'$.

name: Consistent implies satisfiable
statement: If $\Gamma$ is consistent, then $\Gamma$ is satisfiable.

proofs.text: Let $\Gamma'$ be a maximally consistent set s.t. $\Gamma\subset\Gamma'$, then $\Gamma'$ is satisfiable say by a valuation $v$. But $\Gamma\subset\Gamma'$ so $v$ also evaluated everything in $\Gamma$ to true, so $\Gamma$ is satisfiable.

name: Completeness theorem
statement: If $\Gamma\models\phi$, then $\Gamma\vdash\phi$.

proofs.text:
Suppose $\Gamma\models\phi$ but $\Gamma\nvdash\phi$\\
$\Rightarrow\Gamma\cup\{\lnot\phi\}$ is consistent\\
$\Rightarrow\exists v$ s.t. $\tilde{v}(\psi)=T$ for all $\psi\in\Gamma\cup\{\lnot\phi\}$\\
$\Rightarrow\tilde{v}(\psi)=T$ for all $\psi\in\Gamma$ but $\tilde{v}(\phi)=F$\\
$\Rightarrow\Gamma\nvDash\phi$ which is a contradiction

name: Logical consequence and formal proof are equivalent
statement: $\Gamma\models\phi$ iff $\Gamma\vdash\phi$

proofs.text: Completeness + Soundness

name: Compactness theorem
statement: $\Gamma\in Form(\mathcal L_0)$ is satisfiable iff every finite subset of $\Gamma$ is satisfiable.

proofs.text:
\begin{description}
\item[$(\Rightarrow)$] Obvious.
\item[$(\Leftarrow)$] Suppose every finite $\Gamma'\subset\Gamma$ is satisfiable but $\Gamma$ is not. Then $\Gamma$ is inconsistent, ie: $\Gamma\vdash\alpha$ and $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\alpha$ for some $\alpha$.\\
$\Rightarrow$ for some finite $\Gamma'\subset\Gamma$, $\Gamma'\vdash\alpha$ and $\Gamma'\vdash\lnot\alpha$ because proofs are finite\\
$\Rightarrow\Gamma'\models\alpha$ and $\Gamma'\models\lnot\alpha$ by soundness\\
$\Rightarrow\Gamma'$ not satisfiable which is a contradiction.
\end{description}

name: First Order Predicate Calculus
statement:
The language $\mathcal{L}^{FOPC}$ if First Order Predicate Calculus consists of:
\vspace{3mm}\par
\begin{tabular}{p{2cm}p{3cm}p{8cm}}
\textbf{Logical symbols: } & Connectives & $\lnot\ \rightarrow$\\
& Quantifier & $\forall$\\
& Variables & $x_1\ x_2\ x_3\ ...$\\
& Punctuation & $(\ )\ ,$\\
&Equality symbol & $\doteq$\\ [4ex]
\textbf{Non-logical symbols: } & Predicates & $P_n^{(k)}$ for $n\geq0,k\geq1$ where $P_n^{(k)}$ is a $k$-ary predicate symbol.\\
& Functions & $f_n^{(k)}$ for $n\geq0,k\geq1$ where $P_n^{(k)}$ is a $k$-ary function symbol.\\
& Constants & $c_n$ for $n\geq0$
\end{tabular}
\vspace{10mm}\par
The terms of $\mathcal{L}^{FOPC}$ are defined recursively as:
\begin{itemize}
\item Every variable is a term.
\item Every constant is a term.
\item For each $n\geq0,k\geq1$, if $t_1,...,t_k$ are terms then $f_n^{(k)}(t_1,...,t_k)$ is a term.
\end{itemize}
\vspace{10mm}\par
The formulas of $\mathcal{L}^{FOPC}$ are defined as:
\vspace{3mm}\par
\textbf{Atomic formulas:}
\begin{itemize}
\item for $n\geq0,k\geq1$ if $t_1,...,t_k$ are terms then $P_n^{(k)}(t_1,...,t_k)$ is an atomic formula
\item if $t_1$ and $t_2$ are terms then $t_1\doteq t_2$ is an atomic formula
\end{itemize}
\vspace{3mm}\par
\textbf{Recursive formulas:}
\begin{itemize}
\item Any atomic formula is a formula.
\item If $\phi,\psi$ are formulas then $\lnot\phi$ and $(\phi\rightarrow\psi)$ are formulas.
\item If $\phi$ is a formula then for any variable $x_i$, $\forall x_i\phi$ is a formula.
\end{itemize}

name: Bound / Free
statement:
Let $\mathcal L$ be a first-order language, $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L)$ and $x\in\{x_0,x_1,...\}$ a variable occurring in $\phi$.\\
Then $x$ is free in $\phi$ if
\begin{itemize}
\item $\phi$ is atomic
\item $\phi=\lnot\psi$ and $x$ is free in $\psi$
\item $\phi=(\psi\rightarrow\chi)$ and $x$ is free in $\psi$ or $\chi$
\item $\phi=\forall x_i\psi$ and $x$ is free in $\psi$ and $x\neq x_i$
\end{itemize}
Otherwise, $x$ is called bound.

name: First order language
statement: A language is some $\mathcal L\subset\mathcal L^{FOPC}$ that contains all logical symbols but maybe not all non-logical symbols.

name: L-Structure / Assignment
statement:
An interpretation of $\mathcal L$ is an $\mathcal L$-structure
$$\mathcal A=\langle A,(f_A)_{f\in Fnc(\mathcal L)};(P_A)_{P\in Pred(\mathcal L)};(c_A)_{c\in Const(\mathcal L)}\rangle$$
where
\begin{itemize}
\item $A$ is a non-empty set called the domain of $\mathcal A$
\item for each $f=f_n^{(k)}\in\mathcal L$, $f_A:A^k\to A$ is a function
\item for each $P=P_n^{(k)}\in\mathcal L$, $P_A\subset A^k$
\item for each $c\in Const(\mathcal L)$, $c_A\in A$
\end{itemize}
\vspace{1cm}

Now with $\mathcal A=\langle A;...\rangle$ as a fixed $\mathcal L$-structure
\begin{enumerate}
\item An assignment in $\mathcal A$ is a function $v:\{x_0,x_1,...\}\to A$.
\item This extends uniquely to an assignment $\tilde v=\tilde v_A:Terms(\mathcal L)\to A$\\
defined recursively as
\begin{itemize}
\item $\tilde v(x_i) = v(x_i)$ for all $i$
\item $\tilde v(c)=c_A$ for each $c\in Const(\mathcal L)$
\item $\tilde v(f(t_1,...,t_k))=f_A(\tilde v(t_1),...,\tilde v(t_k))$ for each $f\in Fnc(\mathcal L)$ where $\tilde v(t_i)$ are already defined.
\end{itemize}
\item This extends uniquely to an assignment $\tilde v=\tilde v_A:Form(\mathcal L)\to\{T,F\}$\\
defined recursively as
\begin{itemize}
\item For each $P=P_n^{(k)}\in Pred(\mathcal L)$ and for all $t\in Term(\mathcal L)$,\\
$\tilde v(P(t_1,...,t_k))=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}T&\text{if }(\tilde v(t_1),...,\tilde v(t_k))\in P_A\\F&\text{otherwise}\end{array}\right.$
\item For each $t_1,t_2\in Term(\mathcal L)$,\\
$\tilde v(t_1\doteq t_2)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}T&\text{if }\tilde v(t_1)=\tilde v(t_2)\\F&\text{otherwise}\end{array}\right.$
\item For each $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L)$, $\tilde v(\lnot\phi)=T$ iff $\tilde v(\phi)=F$
\item For each $\phi,\psi\in Form(\mathcal L)$, $\tilde v(\phi\rightarrow\psi)=T$ iff $\tilde v(\phi)=F$ or $\tilde v(\psi)=T$
\item For each $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L)$ and variable $x_i$, $\tilde v(\forall x_i\phi)=T$ iff $\tilde v^\star(\phi)=T$ for all assignments $v^\star$ agreeing with $v$ except possibly at $x_i$
\end{itemize}
\end{enumerate}

name: Satisfies / Tautology
statement:
If $\tilde v_A(\phi)=T$ then write $\mathcal A\models\phi[v]$ and say that $\phi$ is true under $\mathcal A$ for assignment $v$.\\
\\
Write $A\models\phi$ and say that $A$ satisfies $\phi$, if $\phi$ is true under $\mathcal A$ for all assignments.\\
\\
Write $\models\phi$ and say that $\phi$ is a tautology, if it is satisfied by all structures.

name: Some abbreviations
Assignments agreeing on free variables
statement:
Let $\mathcal L$ be a language, $\mathcal A$ be an $\mathcal L$-structure, $v,v'$ be assignments in $\mathcal A$ and let $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L)$.\\
If $v(x_i)=v'(x_i)$ for every variable $x_i$ that is free in $\phi$, then $\mathcal A\models\phi[v]$ iff $\mathcal A\models\phi[v']$

proofs.text:
For $\phi$ atomic, every $x_i$ is free in $\phi$ so $v$ and $v'$ are identical. Therefore clearly $\mathcal A\models\phi[v]$ iff $\mathcal A\models\phi[v']$\\
\\
For the inductive step,
\begin{itemize}
\item If $\phi=\lnot\psi$ or $\phi=(\psi\rightarrow\chi)$ then as the set of free variables will be smaller, by the inductive hypothesis it holds for $\psi$ and $\chi$, so therefore the main result holds.
\item If $\phi=\forall x_i\psi$, note that $Free(\phi)=Free(\psi)\setminus\{x_i\}$\\
Assume $\mathcal A\models\forall x_i\psi[v]$ and let $v^\star$ agree with $v$ except possibly at $x_i$, then for all $x_j\in Free(\phi)$, $v^\star(x_j)=v(x_j)=v'(x_j)$.\\
Let $v^+(x_j)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}v(x_j)&\text{if }j\neq i\\v^\star(x_j)&\text{if }j=i\end{array}\right.$, then $v^+$ agrees with $v$ except possibly at $x_i$.\\
Hence $\mathcal A\models\forall x_i\psi[v]\Rightarrow\mathcal A\models\psi[v^+]$, but $v^\star(x_j)=v^+(x_j)$ for all $x_j\in Free(\psi)$.\\
Therefore by the IH, $\mathcal A\models\psi[v^\star]$
\end{itemize}

name: Passing a forall if no free variables
statement: Let  $\mathcal L$ be a language with $\alpha,\beta\in Form(\mathcal L)$, assume the variable $x_i$ has no free occurrences in $\alpha$. Then $\models(\forall x_i(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)\rightarrow(\alpha\rightarrow\forall x_i\beta))$

proofs.text:
Let $\mathcal A$ be an $\mathcal L$-structure and let $v$ be an assignment in $\mathcal A$ such that $\mathcal A\models\forall x_i(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)[v]$, we want to show that $\mathcal A\models(\alpha\rightarrow\forall x_i\beta)[v]$.\\
Suppose $\mathcal A\models\alpha[v]$, let $v^\star$ be an assignment agreeing with $v$ except possibly at $x_i$. $x_i$ is not free in $\alpha$ $\Rightarrow\mathcal A\models\alpha[v^\star]$ $\Rightarrow\mathcal A\models(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)[v^\star]$ $\Rightarrow\mathcal A\models\beta[v^\star]$ $\Rightarrow\mathcal A\models\forall x_i\beta[v]$ $\Rightarrow\mathcal A\models(\alpha\rightarrow\forall x_i\beta)[v]$

name: Statement / Sentence
statement:
If $\phi$ has no free occurrences of any variable, then it is called a statement or a sentence. Write $\mathcal A\models\phi$ is $\mathcal A\models\phi[v]$ for any $v$.\\
Say $\phi$ is true in $\mathcal A$, or that $\mathcal A$ is a model of $\phi$.

name: Substitution
Substitution as an assignment
statement:
Let $\mathcal A$ be an $\mathcal L$-structure, $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L)$ and $t$ be a term free for the variable $x_i$ in $\phi$.\\
Let $v$ be an assignment in $\mathcal A$ and define
$$v'(x_j)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}v(x_j)&i\neq j\\\tilde{v}(t)&i=j\end{array}\right.$$
Then $\mathcal A\models\phi[v']$ iff $\mathcal A\models\phi[t/x_i][v]$

proofs.text:
\begin{enumerate}
\item For $u\in Term(\mathcal L)$, let $u[t/x_i]$ be the term obtained by replacing each occurrence of $x_i$ in $u$ by $t$. Therefore $\tilde v'(u)=\tilde v(u[t/x_i])$, by induction on the length of $u$,
\begin{itemize}
\item If $u=x_i$ then $u[t/x_i]=t$, so $\tilde v'(u)=\tilde v(t)=\tilde v(u[t/x_i])$
\item If $u=x_j$ for $i\neq j$ then $u[t/x_i]=u$, so $\tilde v'(u)=v(x_j)=\tilde v(x_j)=\tilde v(u[t/x_i])$
\item If $u=c$ then $u[t/x_i]=u$, so $\tilde v'(u)=\tilde v'(c)=\tilde v(c)=\tilde v(u[t/x_i])$
\item If $u=f(t_1,...,t_k)$ then $u[t/x_i]=f(t_1[t/x_i],...,t_k[t/x_i])$,\\so $\tilde v'(u)=f_A(\tilde v'(t_1[t/x_i]),...,\tilde v'(t_k[t/x_i]))=f_A(\tilde v(t_1[t/x_i]),...,\tilde v(t_k[t/x_i]))=\tilde v(u[t/x_i])$ by the inductive hypothesis.
\end{itemize}
\item If $\phi$ is atomic, say $\phi=P(t_1,...,t_k)$, then
\\\\
\begin{tabular}{lll}
&$\mathcal A\models\phi[v']$\\
iff&$P_A(\tilde v'(t_1),...,\tilde v'(t_k))$&by def $\models$\\
iff&$P_A(\tilde v(t_1[t/x_i]),...,\tilde v(t_k[t/x_I]))$&by (1)\\
iff&$\mathcal A\models P(t_1[t/x_i],...,t_k[t/x_i])$&by def $\models$\\
iff&$\mathcal A\models\phi[t/x_i][v]$
\end{tabular}
\\\vspace{4mm}\\
Similarly for $\phi=t_1\doteq t_2$
\item Induction step\\
\\
The cases $\lnot$ and $\rightarrow$ are routine, the only interesting case is $\phi=\forall x_j\psi$.\\
\\
Assume the lemma holds for $\psi$
\begin{description}
\item[Case 1: ]$j=i$\\
$\Rightarrow\phi[t/x_i]=\phi$ by definition\\
$x_i=x_j\not\in Free(\phi)$\\
$\Rightarrow v$ and $v'$ agree on all $x\in Free(\phi)$\\
$\Rightarrow$ by lemma, $\mathcal A\models\phi[v']$ iff $\mathcal A\models\phi[v]$ iff $\mathcal A\models\phi[t/x_i][v]$
\item[Case 2: ]$j\neq i$
\begin{description}
\item[$(\Rightarrow)$ ] Suppose $\mathcal A\models\forall x_j\psi[v']$, we want to show that $\mathcal A\models\forall x_j\psi[t/x_i][v]$.\\
Let $v^\star$ agree with $v$ except possibly at $x_j$, define ${v^\star}'(x_k)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}v^\star(x_k)&\text{if }k\neq i\\\tilde v^\star(t)&\text{if }k=i\end{array}\right.$\\
$t$ is free for $x_i$ in $\phi$ implies that $t$ is free for $x_i$ in $\psi$ and $t$ does not contain $x_j$. By the inductive hypothesis it is enough to show that $\mathcal A\models\psi[{v^\star}']$\\
In fact, ${v^\star}'$ and $v'$ agree except at $x_j$ as $v'(x_i)=\tilde v(t)=\tilde v^\star(t)={v^\star}'(x_i)$. Therefore $\mathcal A\models\psi[{v^\star}']$
\item[$(\Leftarrow)$ ] Similar.
\end{description}
\end{description}
\end{enumerate}

name: Tautology of substitutions
statement:
For any $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L)$ and $t\in Term(\mathcal L)$ such that $t$ is free for variable $x_i$ in $\phi$, then
$$\models(\forall x_i\phi\rightarrow\phi[t/x_i])$$

name: Formal system of proof
statement:
Associate with each first order language $\mathcal L$ the formal system $K(\mathcal L)$ with the following axioms for formulas $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in Form(\mathcal L)$ and term $t\in Term(\mathcal L)$
\begin{description}
\item[Axioms]\
\begin{description}
\item[(A1) ] $(\alpha\rightarrow(\beta\rightarrow\alpha))$
\item[(A2) ] $((\alpha\rightarrow(\beta\rightarrow\gamma))\rightarrow((\alpha\rightarrow\beta)\rightarrow(\alpha\rightarrow\gamma)))$
\item[(A3) ] $((\lnot\beta\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)\rightarrow(\alpha\rightarrow\beta))$
\item[(A4) ] $(\forall x_i\alpha\rightarrow\alpha[t/x_i])$ where $t$ is free for $x_i$ in $\alpha$
\item[(A5) ] $(\forall x_i(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)\rightarrow(\alpha\rightarrow\forall x_i\beta))$ provided $x_i\not\in Free(\alpha)$
\item[(A6) ] $\forall x_ix_i\doteq x_i$
\item[(A7) ] $(x_i\doteq x_j\rightarrow(\phi\rightarrow\phi'))$ where $\phi$ is atomic and $\phi'$ is obtained by replacing some occurrences of $x_i$ in $\phi$ by $x_j$
\end{description}
\item[Rules]\ 
\begin{description}
\item[(MP) ] From $\alpha$ and $(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)$ deduce $\beta$
\item[($\forall$ generalisation) ] From $\alpha$ infer $\forall x_i\alpha$
\end{description}
\end{description}
\ \vspace{1cm}\\
$\phi$ is a theorem of $K(\mathcal L)$ (written $\vdash\phi$) if there is a finite sequence $\phi_1,...,\phi_n$ of $\mathcal L$-formulas with $\phi_n=\phi$ and each $\phi_i$ is an axiom or derived from earlier $\phi_j$ by MP or $\forall$.\\
\\
For $\Gamma\subset Form(\mathcal L)$, $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L)$, write $\Gamma\vdash\phi$ (say $\phi$ is derivable from $\Gamma$) if $\vdash\phi$ with the additional allowance that $\phi_i$ may be from $\Gamma$. Make the restriction that $\forall$ may only be used for variables $x_i$ not occuring free in any formula in $\Gamma$.

name: Soundness of predicate calculus
statement: If $\Gamma\vdash\phi$ then $\Gamma\models\phi$

proofs.text:
Induction on the length of derivation\\
\\
It is clear that A1, A2, A3 are logically valid as they are the same as for propositional calculus.\\
So are A4 and A5 by earlier corollaries.\\
Also A6 is logically valid, by definition.\\
\\
For A7, let $\mathcal A$ be an $\mathcal L$-structure and let $v$ be an assignment in $\mathcal A$, suppose that $\mathcal A\models x_i\doteq x_j[v]$ and $\mathcal A\models\phi[v]$. We want to show that $\mathcal A\models\phi'[v]$ (with $\phi$ atomic).\\
Now, $v(x_i)=v(x_j)\Rightarrow\tilde v(t')=\tilde v(t)$ for any term $t'$ obtained from $t$ by replacing some of the $x_i$ by $x_j$.\\
If $\phi=P(t_1,...,t_k)$ then $\phi'=P(t_1',...,t_k')$
$$\begin{array}{rcl}
\mathcal A\models\phi[v]&\text{iff}&P_A(\tilde v(t_1),...,\tilde v(t_k))\\
&\text{iff}&P_A(\tilde v(t_1'),...,\tilde v(t_k'))\\
&\text{iff}&\mathcal A\models P(t_1',...,t_k')[v]\\
&\text{iff}&\mathcal A\models\phi'[v]
\end{array}$$
Similarly if $\phi=t_1\doteq t_2$.\\
\\
So now all axioms are logically valid.\\
\\
MP is sound for any $\mathcal A$ and $v$ as\\
$\mathcal A\models\alpha[v]$ and $\mathcal A\models(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)[v]$ implies $\mathcal A\models\beta[v]$\\
\\
$\forall$ generalisation: Assume the IH for any $\mathcal A$ and $v$,\\
If $\mathcal A\models\psi[v]$ for all $\psi\in\Gamma$ then $\mathcal A\models\alpha[v]$ $(\star)$\\
so we now want to show that $\mathcal A\models\forall x_i\alpha[v]$ for such $\mathcal A,\ v$\\
Let $v^\star$ agree with $v$ except possibly at $x_i$ for $x_i\not\in Free(\psi)$ for all $\psi\in\Gamma$\\
$\Rightarrow\mathcal A\models\psi[v^\star]$ for all $\psi\in\Gamma$\\
$\Rightarrow\mathcal A\models\alpha[v^\star]$ (by $(\star)$)\\
$\Rightarrow\mathcal A\models\forall x_i\alpha[v]$ as required

name: Deduction theorem
statement: If $\Gamma\cup\{\psi\}\vdash\phi$ then $\Gamma\vdash(\psi\rightarrow\phi)$

proofs.text:
Same as for propositional calculus but with one more step in the induction...\\
\\
Assume as the IH that $\Gamma\vdash(\psi\rightarrow\phi_i)$, to show that $\Gamma\vdash(\psi\rightarrow\forall x_i\phi_j)$ where generalisation $\forall$ has been used to infer $\forall x_i\phi_j$ under the hypothesis $\Gamma\cup\{\psi\}$\\
$\Rightarrow x_i\in Free(\gamma)$ for all $\gamma\in\Gamma$ and $x_i\not\in Free(\psi)$\\
$\Rightarrow$ by the IH and $\forall$: $\Gamma\vdash\forall x_i(\psi\rightarrow\phi_j)$\\
$\Rightarrow$ A5: $\vdash(\forall x_i(\psi\rightarrow\phi_j)\rightarrow(\psi\rightarrow\forall x_i\phi_j))$ since $x_i\not\in Free(\psi)$\\
$\Rightarrow$ MP: $\Gamma\vdash(\psi\rightarrow\forall x_i\phi_j)$ as required

name: Consistent
statement:
A set $\Gamma$ of sentences is called consistent if for no sentence $\phi$ we have both $\Gamma\vdash\phi$ and $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\phi$\\
\\
A set $\Gamma$ of sentences is called maximal consistent if for any sentence $\phi$, precisely one of $\Gamma\vdash\phi$ or $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\phi$

name: Witnessing
statement: A set $\Gamma$ of sentences is called witnessing if for all formulas $\phi$ such that $Free(\phi)\subset\{x_i\}$ and $\Gamma\vdash\exists x_i\phi$, there exists a constant $c_j$ such that $\Gamma\vdash\phi[c_j/x_i]$

name: Term model
statement:
Let $\mathcal L$ be a first-order language without the equality sign and let $\Gamma$ be a set of sentences of $\mathcal L$. Then the term model of $\Gamma$ is the $\mathcal L$-structure $\mathcal A$ is defined by
$$\text{has model }A=\{t\in Terms(\mathcal L): t\text{ is closed}\}$$
$$\begin{array}{rcl}
P_A(t_1,...,t_k)&\text{iff}&\Gamma\vdash P(t_1,...,t_k)\\
f_A(t_1,...,t_k)&=&f(t_1,...,t_k)\\
c_A&=&c
\end{array}$$

name: Term assignment as substitution
statement:
Let  $\mathcal A$ be the term model of $\Gamma\subset Sent(\mathcal L)$ and let $v$ be an assignment in $\mathcal A$ given by $v(x_i)=s_i$.\\
Then for any term $u$, $\tilde v(u)=u[\vec s/\vec x]$.\\
\\
(Where by $u[\vec s/\vec x]$ we mean replacing each $x_i$ by $s_i$ simultaneously.)

name: Criterion for an assignment of term model for a maximal consistent witnessing set
statement:
Let $\mathcal L$ be a first-order language without the equality sign. Let $\mathcal A$ be the term model of a maximal consistent witnessing set of sentences $\Gamma$ and let $v$ be an assignment in $\mathcal A$ given by $v(x_i)=s_i$.\\
Then for any formula $\phi$, $\mathcal A\models\phi[v]$ iff $\Gamma\vdash\phi[\vec s/\vec x]$.

proofs.text:
The proof is by induction.
\begin{description}
\item[$\phi=P(t_1,...,t_k)$ :] Then $\mathcal A\models\phi[v]=\tilde v(\phi)=P_A(\tilde v(t_1),...,\tilde v(t_k))$ which is the same as $P_A(t_1[\vec s/\vec x],...,t_k[\vec s/\vec x])$. By the definition of the term model, that is iff $\Gamma\vdash P(t_1[\vec s/\vec x],...,t_k[\vec s/\vec x])=P(t_1,...,t_k)[\vec s/\vec x]=\phi[\vec s/\vec x]$
\item[$\phi=\lnot\psi$ :] Then $\mathcal A\models\phi[v]$ iff $\mathcal A\not\models\psi[v]$, which is by the induction hypothesis iff $\Gamma\not\vdash\psi[\vec s/\vec x]$. Since $\Gamma$ is maximal consistent, that is exactly when $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\psi[\vec s/\vec x]=\phi[\vec s/\vec x]$
\item[$\phi=(\psi\rightarrow\chi)$ :] Then $\mathcal A\models\phi[v]$ iff $\mathcal A\models\lnot\psi[v]$ or $\mathcal A\models\chi[v]$, which is by the IH iff $\Gamma\not\vdash\psi[\vec s/\vec x]$ or $\Gamma\vdash\chi[\vec s/\vec x]$. In either case we can prove using a tautology and MP that $\Gamma\vdash(\psi[\vec s/\vec x]\rightarrow\chi[\vec s/\vec x])=(\psi\rightarrow\chi)[\vec s/\vec x]$.
\item[$\phi=\forall x_i\psi$ :] First suppose that $\mathcal A\models\forall x_i\psi[v]$ but not $\Gamma\vdash\forall x_i\psi[\vec s/\vec x]$. Let $\phi'$ be the formula $\phi$ with $x_i$ replaced by $s_i$ throughout for each $i$. Since $\Gamma$ is maximal consistent, we must have $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\forall x_i\phi'$, from which it is easy to prove that also $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\forall x_i\lnot\lnot\phi'=\exists x_i\lnot\phi'$. Since $\Gamma$ is witnessing, we must also have $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\phi'[c/x_i]$ for some constant $c$. If we now define
$$s_j^\star=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}s_j&\text{if }j\neq i\\c&\text{if }j=i\end{array}\right.\text{ and }v^\star(x_j)=s_j^\star$$
then $\psi'[c/x_i]$ is exactly $\psi[\vec s^\star/\vec x]$. By the IH, $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\psi'[c/x_i]=\lnot\psi[\vec s^\star/\vec x]$ implies $\mathcal A\models\lnot\psi[v^\star]$. But $v^\star$ is $x_i$-equivalent to $v$, so this is a contradiction to $\mathcal A\models\forall x_i\psi[v]$.\\
\\
Conversely, suppose that $\mathcal A\not\models\forall x_i\psi[v]$. Then there exists at least one $x_i$-equivalent assignment $v^\star$ to $v$, such that $\mathcal A\not\models\psi[v^\star]$. Defining
$$s_j^\star=v^\star(x_j)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}s_j&\text{if }j\neq i\\v^\star(x_i)&\text{if }j=i\end{array}\right.$$
we get by the IH that $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\psi[\vec s^\star/\vec x]$ and hence $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\psi'[v^\star(x_i)/x_i]$. But then $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\forall x_i\psi'$ (otherwise $\Gamma\vdash\forall x_i\psi'$ by the maximality of $\Gamma$ and then $\Gamma\vdash\psi'[v^\star(x_i)/x_i]$ using A4 and MP). From the definition of $\psi'$ this is the same as $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\forall x_i\psi[\vec s/\vec x]$, which implies that $\Gamma\not\vdash\forall x_i\psi[\vec s/\vec x]$.
\end{description}

name: A term model of a maximal consistent witnessing set is actually a model
statement: Let $\mathcal A$ be the term model of a maximal consistent witnessing set $\Gamma\subset Sent(\mathcal L)$. Then $\mathcal A\models\Gamma$.

proofs.text: For any $\psi\in\Gamma$ and for any closed terms $s_i$, $\psi[\vec s/\vec x]=\psi$ since $\psi$ is just a sentence. Trivially $\Gamma\vdash\psi$, so by the above lemma, $\mathcal A\models\psi[v]$ for any valuation $v$, hence $\mathcal A\models\psi$. This holds for any $\psi\in\Gamma$, so $\mathcal A\models\Gamma$.

name: Tautology for converting a forall
statement:
For any $\alpha,\beta\in Form(\mathcal L)$ such that $x_i\not\in Free(\beta)$ we have
$$\vdash(\forall x_i(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)\rightarrow(\exists x_i\alpha\rightarrow\beta))$$

proofs.text:
\begin{tabular}{ll}
$\forall x_i(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)\vdash(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)$ & by (A4) and DT\\
$\forall x_i(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)\vdash(\lnot\beta\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)$ & by tautology and MP\\
$\forall x_i(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)\vdash\forall x_i(\lnot\beta\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)$ & by ($\forall$)\\
$\forall x_i(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)\vdash(\lnot\beta\rightarrow\forall x_i\lnot\alpha)$ & by (A5) and MP\\
$\forall x_i(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)\vdash(\lnot\forall x_i\lnot\alpha\rightarrow\beta)$ & by tautology and MP\\
$\vdash(\forall x_i(\alpha\rightarrow\beta)\rightarrow(\exists x_i\alpha\rightarrow\beta))$ & by tautology and DT
\end{tabular}

name: Satisfaction of a substituted formula
statement: Let $\Gamma\subset Form(\mathcal L)$ and $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L)$ with only $x_i$ occurring free in $\phi$. If $c_j$ is a constant symbol not occurring in $\Gamma$ nor $\phi$, and $\Gamma\vdash\phi[c_j/x_i]$, then $\Gamma\vdash\phi$.

proofs.text: The proof $\Gamma\vdash\phi[c_j/x_i]$ only uses a finite subset $\Gamma'$ of formulas from $\Gamma$. If $x_k$ is a variable not occurring $\Gamma'$ nor in the proof of $\phi[c_j/x_i]$ from $\Gamma'$, it is easy to see by induction on the proof that also $\Gamma'\vdash\phi[x_k/x_i]$. By generalisation on $x_k$, (A4) and MP we get that $\Gamma'\vdash\phi[x_i/x_k][x_k/x_i]=\phi$. By the thinning rule also $\Gamma\vdash\phi$.

name: Increasing a consistent set with a substituted existential formula
statement: If $\Gamma\subset Sent(\mathcal L)$ is consistent, $\exists x_i\phi\in Sent(\mathcal L)$, $\Gamma\vdash\exists x_i\phi$, and $c_j$ does not occur in $\phi$ nor in $\Gamma$, then $\Gamma\cup\{\phi[c_j/x_i]\}$ is consistent.

proofs.text:
Suppose that $\Gamma\cup\{\phi[c_j/x_i]\}$ is not consistent, so that $\Gamma\cup\{\phi[c_j/x_i]\}\vdash\alpha$ and $\Gamma\cup\{\phi[c_j/x_i]\}\vdash\lnot\alpha$ for some formula $\alpha$. By the deduction theorem, we get that $\Gamma\vdash(\phi[c_j/x_i]\rightarrow\alpha)$ and $\Gamma\vdash(\phi[c_j/x_i]\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)$. Since from $\alpha$ and $\lnot\alpha$ we can deduce any formula, we can assume that $\alpha$ is a sentence and that $c_j$ does not occur in $\alpha$. Then the above lemma applies and we get that $\Gamma\vdash(\phi\rightarrow\alpha)$ and $\Gamma\vdash(\phi\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)$.\\
Since $\Gamma\subset Sent(\mathcal L)$, we can use the generalisation rule to infer $\Gamma\vdash\forall x_i(\phi\rightarrow\alpha)$ and $\Gamma\vdash\forall x_i(\phi\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)$. Since also $\alpha\in Sent(\mathcal L)$, we can use a previously proved tautology and MP to get that $\Gamma\vdash(\exists x_i\phi\rightarrow\alpha)$ and $\Gamma\vdash(\exists x_i\phi\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)$, therefore also $\Gamma\vdash\alpha$ and $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\alpha$ by MP. This is a contradiction to the consistency of $\Gamma$.

name: A consistent set can always be increased
statement: If $\Gamma\subset Sent(\mathcal L)$ is a consistent and $\phi\in Sent(\mathcal L)$, then either $\Gamma\cup\{\phi\}$ or $\Gamma\cup\{\lnot\phi\}$ is consistent.

proofs.text: This follows from propositional logic, since all the deductions still apply.

name: Every consistent set of sentences has a model
statement: Let $\mathcal L$ be a first-order language without the equality sign. Then every consistent set of sentences of $\mathcal L$ has a model.

proofs.text:
Let $\Gamma\subset Sent(\mathcal L)$ be consistent, and for convenience assume that it contains no odd-indexed constants $c_{2m+1}$. If it does, just relabel the constants $c_j\mapsto c_{2j}$ and observe that the relabeled set is still consistent, and if the relabeled set has a model, then $\Gamma$ also does. Denote $\mathcal L'=\mathcal L\cup\{c_i\}_{i\in\mathbb N}$ and let $\phi_1,\phi_2,...$ be an enumeration of $Sent(\mathcal L')$.\\
Define $\Gamma_0=\emptyset$, noting that $\Gamma\cup\Gamma_0$ is consistent by the assumption on $\Gamma$. For any $n\in\mathcal N$, assuming that $\Gamma\cup\Gamma_{n-1}$ is consistent, define $\Gamma_n$ as follows. Let
$$\Gamma_{n-{1\over2}}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\Gamma_{n-1}\cup\{\phi_n\}&\text{if }\Gamma\cup\Gamma_{n-1}\cup\{\phi_n\}\text{ is consistent}\\\Gamma_{n-1}\cup\{\lnot\phi_n\}&\text{otherwise}\end{array}\right.$$
Using a previous lemma, this is well-defined and $\Gamma\cup\Gamma_{n-{1\over2}}$ is consistent. If $\Gamma_{n-{1\over2}}=\Gamma_{n-1}\cup\{\lnot\phi_n\}$ or $\phi_n\neq\exists x_i\psi$, let just $\Gamma_n=\Gamma_{n-{1\over2}}$. However, if $\phi_n\in\Gamma_{n-{1\over2}}$ with $\phi_n=\exists x_i\psi$ for some formula $\psi$, then choose $m$ large enough so that $c_{2m+1}$ does not occur in any formula in $\Gamma\cup\Gamma_{n-{1\over2}}\cup\{\psi\}$ and let $\Gamma_n=\Gamma_{n-{1\over2}}\cup\{\psi[c_{2m+1}/x_i]\}$. By a previous lemma, $\Gamma\cup\Gamma_n$ is consistent.\\
Now let $\Gamma'=\Gamma\cup\bigcup_{n\in\mathbb N}\Gamma_n$. Similarly as in the argument for propositional calculus, $\Gamma'$ is consistent, and by construction it is also maximal and witnessing. Then by a corollary, it has a model $\mathcal A$, but since $\Gamma\subset\Gamma'$, $\mathcal A$ is also a model of $\Gamma$.

name: Completeness theorem (reduced version)
statement: Let $\mathcal L$ be a first-order language without the equality sign, let $\Gamma\subset Sent(\mathcal L)$ and $\phi\in Sent(\mathcal L)$. If $\Gamma\models\phi$, then $\Gamma\vdash\phi$.

proofs.text: If $\Gamma$ is inconsistent, the claim is trivial, so suppose $\Gamma$ is consistent. Since $\Gamma\models\phi$, $\Gamma\cup\{\lnot\phi\}$ does not have a model, and hence $\Gamma\cup\{\lnot\phi\}$ is inconsistent. By a corollary, or using the tautology $((\lnot\phi\rightarrow\alpha)\rightarrow((\lnot\phi\rightarrow\lnot\alpha)\rightarrow\phi))$, we get that $\Gamma\vdash\phi$.

name: Compactness theorem
statement: Let $\mathcal L$ be a first-order language and $\Gamma\subset Sent(\mathcal L)$. Then $\Gamma$ has a model if and only if every finite subset of $\Gamma$ has a model.

proofs.text: The forward direction is trivial. Conversely suppose that $\Gamma$ does not have a model, so that $\Gamma\models\phi$ for every $\phi\in Form(\mathcal L)$, i.e. it is inconsistent. Taking $\alpha$ such that $\Gamma\vdash\alpha$ and $\Gamma\vdash\lnot\alpha$, these two proofs only use a finite subset $\Gamma'$ or $\Gamma$. But this means that $\Gamma'\vdash\alpha$ and $\Gamma'\vdash\lnot\alpha$, so that $\Gamma'$ is also inconsistent. Therefore $\Gamma'$ does not have a model either.

name: ZFC
statement:
ZFC (Zermelo-Frankel set theory with axiom of choice) is a first order language with one non-logical symbol; the binary predicate $\in$, denoting membership.\\
\\
Within it, everything is a set. Extra notation will be introduced but everything is built from a collection of axioms and the binary relation of membership.

name: ZF1 - Extensionality
statement:
Two sets are equal iff they have the same elements
\vskip 2mm\hspace*{6mm} eg: $\forall x\forall y(x=y\leftrightarrow\forall z(z\in x\leftrightarrow z\in y))$

name: ZF2 - Null set
statement:
There exists a set with no elements, denoted $\emptyset$
\vskip 2mm\hspace*{6mm} eg: $\exists x\forall y(\lnot(y\in x))$

name: The empty set is unique
statement: The empty set is unique

proofs.text:
(Only uses ZF1 and ZF2)\\
\\
By ZF2, there exists an empty set $x$. Suppose $y$ is also an empty set, then by ZF1 they are equal as the have the same elements. Hence $x=y$ so the empty set is unique

name: ZF3 - Unordered pair
statement: If $x$ and $y$£ are sets then there is a set whose elements are precisely $x$ and $y$. It is denoted $\{x,y\}$

name: The unordered pair is unique
statement: Given $x$ and $y$, the set afforded by ZF3 is unique.

proofs.text: Supposing $z$ was a set with precisely $x$ and $y$ as its elements, then by ZF1 $z=\{x,y\}$.

name: Singleton sets exist
statement: If $x$ is a set, then the singleton set $\{x\}$ is a set.

proofs.text: Observe that $\{x\}=\{x,x\}$ which exists by ZF3.

name: Ordered pair
statement:
Let $x,y$ be sets, the set $\{\{x\},\{x,y\}\}$ is called the ordered pair of $x$ and $y$ and is denoted $\langle x,y\rangle$.\\
The set $x$ is the first coordinate and the set $y$ is the second coordinate of the ordered pair.

name: Equality of ordered pairs
statement: Let $x, y, u, v$ be sets, if $\langle x,y\rangle=\langle u,v\rangle$ then $x=u$ and $y=v$.

proofs.text:
Suppose that $\{\{x\},\{x,y\}\}=\{\{u\},\{u,v\}\}$\\
\\
Suppose $x=y$, then
$$\{x,y\}=\{x\}\text{ and }\{\{x\},\{x,y\}\}=\{\{x\},\{x\}\}=\{\{x\}\}$$
is a set with just one element. By ZF1 each element of the RHS is an element of the LHS, so
$$\{u\}=\{x\}\text{ and }\{u,v\}=\{x\}$$
so that $\{u,v\}=\{u\}$ which implies that $u=v$ and $u=x$, so $x=y=y=v$. If $u=v$ then a symmetrical argument gives $x=y=u=v$.\\
\\
So we can assume that $x\neq y$ and $u\neq v$. Since $\{x\}$ is an element of the LHS, it must be an element of the RHS. Then we are in one of two cases.
\begin{description}
\item[Case 1: ]$\{x\}=\{u,v\}$, which implies $u=x$, $v=x$, hence $u=v$, which is a contradiction.
\item[Case 2: ]$\{x\}=\{u\}$, which implies $x=u$.
\end{description}
Next $\{x,y\}$ is an element of the RHS, and $\{x,y\}=\{u\}$ leads to a contradiction. So we have $\{x,y\}=\{u,v\}$, now $y$ must equal one of the elements $u,v$, but $y=u$ and $u=x$ leads to $x=y$, a contradiction. Hence $y=v$.

name: ZF4 - Unions
statement: Given a set $x$, there is a set consisting of all the elements of all the elements of $x$, denoted $\bigcup x$.

name: Unions of two sets exist
statement: If $x$ and $y$ are sets, the union of $x$ and $y$ is a set, denoted $x\cup y$.

proofs.text: By ZF3, form $z=\{x,y\}$, then $\bigcup z$ is the union of $x$ and $y$.

name: ZF5 - Comprehension scheme
statement:
If $\phi(z,w_1,...,w_k)$ is a formula in our first order language and $x, w_1, ..., w_k$ are sets, then there is a set $y$ consisting of the elements $z$ of $x$ for which $\phi(z,w_1,...,w_k$ holds.\\
It is denoted $y=\{z\in x:\phi(z,w_1,...,w_k)\}$

name: Intersections and differences of sets exist
statement: If $x,y$ are sets, then so are their intersection $x\cap y$ and their difference $x\setminus y$

proofs.text:
By comprehension using $\phi(z, w)=z\in w$,
\vskip 1mm\hspace*{6mm}$x\cap y=\{z\in x:\phi(z, y)\}$
\\\\
By comprehension using $\psi(\, w)=\lnot(z\in w)$,
\vskip 1mm\hspace*{6mm}$x\setminus y=\{z\in x:\psi(z, y)\}$

name: Intersection of elements of a set
statement: Let $x$ be a set, then the intersection of all elements of $x$ is a set, denoted $\bigcap x$.

proofs.text:
The set $\bigcup x$ contains the elements we want, so
$$\bigcap x=\{z\in\bigcup x: \forall y(y\in x\rightarrow z\in y)\}$$

name: There is no set of all sets
statement: There is no set of all sets.

proofs.text:
If $x$ is a set, we can comprehend $y=\{z\in x: z\not\in z\}$.\\
But if there were a set of all sets, then we get Russell's paradox.

name: Class
statement:
A class is a collection of the form $\mathbb X=\{x:\phi(x)\}$ where $\phi$ is a formula and $x$ ranges over all sets.
\vskip 1mm\hspace*{6mm}Eg: $\mathbb V=\{x:x=x\}$ is the universe of all sets.\\
\\
A class which is not a set is called a proper class.

name: ZF6 - Powerset
statement: Let $x$ be a set, there exists a set whose elements are precisely the subsets of $x$, denoted $\mathcal P(x)$.

name: Cartesian product
statement: Let $X,Y$ be sets, there exists a set whose elements are precisely all the ordered pairs $\langle x,r\rangle$ where $x\in X$ and $y\in Y$, called the Cartesian product of $X$ and $Y$ and denoted $X\times Y$.

proofs.text:
The key observation is that if $x\in X$ and $y\in Y$ then $\{x\}\in\mathcal P(X\cup Y)$ and $\{x,y\}\in\mathcal P(X\cup Y)$. Therefore $\langle x,y\rangle\in\mathcal P(\mathcal P(X\cup Y))=P$.\\
Then by comprehension,
$$Z=\{z\in P:\exists x\exists y(x\in X\land y\in Y\land z=\langle x,y\rangle)\}$$
This above set $Z$ is the desired Cartesian product and is uniquely determined.

name: Relation
statement:
Let $X,Y$ be sets, a relation between $X$ and $Y$ is a subset $R\subset X\times Y$.\\
As shorthand, we may write $xRy$ to mean $\langle x,y\rangle\in R$

name: Function
statement:
A relation $R\subset X\times Y$ is called a function from $X$ to $Y$ if for all $x\in X$ there exists precisely one $y\in Y$ such that $xRy$, write $f(z)=y$.\\
\\
Note that the set of all relations between $X$ and $Y$ is just $\mathcal P(X\times Y)$, hence inside this we can comprehend the set of all functions from $X$ to $Y$, denote it $Y^X$.\\
\\
For a function $f$, the domain and range are defined as
$$\begin{array}{r@{\hspace{1mm}}l}Dom(f)=&\{x\in\bigcup\bigcup f:\exists y\in\bigcup\bigcup f,\ \langle x,y\rangle\in f\}\\Range(f)=&\{y\in\bigcup\bigcup f:\exists x\in\bigcup\bigcup f,\ \langle x,y\rangle\in f\}\end{array}$$

name: Equivalence relation
Order relation
Weakening an order relation
statement: Let $S$ be a strict partial order on $X$, define a relation $R=S\cup\{\langle x,x\rangle:x\in X\}$ and call it "$S$ or equal to". Then $R$ is a weak partial order on $X$, furthermore if $S$ is total then $R$ is total.

name: Natural numbers
statement:
Define the successor of a set $x$ as $x^+=x\cup\{x\}$\\
Then define $0=\emptyset$, $1=0^+=\{0\}$, $2=1^+=\{0,1\}$, $3=2^+=\{0,1,2\}$, ...

name: Inductive set
statement: A set $x$ is called inductive for a successor set, if $\emptyset\in x$ and $y\in x\Rightarrow y^+\in x$.

name: ZF7 - Infinity
statement: There exists an inductive set.

name: There exists a minimal inductive set
statement: There is a unique inductive set that is contained in every inductive set, denoted $\mathbb N$ or $\omega$.

proofs.text:
The statement "$x$ is an inductive set" is expressible by a formula
$$\phi(x)=(\emptyset\in x\land\forall y(y\in x\rightarrow y^+\in x))$$
Let $X$ be an inductive set, (exists by ZF7), set $N=\{x\in X:\forall y(\phi(y)\rightarrow x\in y)\}$\\
\\
The claims are than
\begin{enumerate}
\item $N$ is an inductive set
\item $N$ is a subset of every inductive set
\item $N$ is unique with these properties
\end{enumerate}
Clearly $x\in X\Rightarrow x\in y$ for every inductive set $y$. So $N$ is contained within every inductive set.\\
Suppose $x\in N$, let $Y$ be an inductive set, then $x\in Y\Rightarrow x^+\in Y\Rightarrow x^+\in N$. So $N$ is an inductive set.\\
Finally, suppose $N'$ is inductive and a subset of all inductive sets, then $N\subset N'$ and $N'\subset N$, hence $N=N'$ by extensionality.

name: Proof by induction
statement: Suppose $\phi(x)$ is a property of natural numbers such that $\phi(0)$ holds, and for all $n$ if $\phi(n)$ holds then $\phi(n^+)$ holds, then $\phi(n)$ holds for all $n\in\mathbb N$.

proofs.text: Let $X=\{x\in\mathbb N:\phi(x)\}$, then $X$ is an inductive set. Therefore $\mathbb N\subset X$, so $X=\mathbb N$ and hence $\phi(n)$ holds for all $n\in\mathbb N$.

name: Less than of equal to
statement: Define $R_\leq=\{\langle n,m\rangle\in\mathbb N\times\mathbb N:(n\in m)\lor(n=m)\}$. Write $n\leq m$ to mean $\langle n,m\rangle\in R_\leq$

name: Less than or equal to criterion
statement: Let $n,m\in\mathbb N$, then $m\leq n$ iff $m\subset n$.

name: Less than or equal to is a weak total order
statement: The relation $R_\leq$ on $\mathbb N$ is a weak total order.

proofs.text:
It is a weak partial order because $\subset$ is one. So it is reflexive, antisymmetric and transitive.\\
\\
By induction prove $\phi(n)$ : "if $m\in\mathbb N$ and $m\not\leq n$, then $n\leq m$"
\begin{itemize}
\item Suppose $n=0$, then $0=\emptyset\leq m$ for any $m$, so $\phi(0)$ holds.
\item Suppose $\phi(n)$ holds and $m\not\leq n^+$, then $m\not\leq n$ by transitivity, so $n\leq m$ by IH.\\
Since $m\neq n$, $n\in m$. Then as $n\subset m$ and $n\in m$, $n^+\subset m$, so $n^+\leq m$
\end{itemize}
Hence $R_\leq$ is total.

name: Every natural number except zero is a successor
statement: Every element of $\mathbb N$ is either $0$ or the successor $x^+$ of a unique $x\in\mathbb N$.

name: Strong induction
statement: Suppose $\phi(x)$ is a property of natural numbers and for every $n\in\mathbb N$, if $\phi(m)$ holds for all $m\in n$ then $\phi(n)$ holds. Then $\phi(n)$ golds for all $n\in\mathbb N$.

proofs.text:
We set $\psi(n)$ : "if $m\in n$ then $\phi(m)$ holds" and prove $\forall n\psi(n)$ by induction.\\
Then if $\phi(m)$ holds for all $m\in n$ then $\phi(n)$ holds (by hypothesis).\\
But then $\phi(m)$ holds for all $m\in n^+$, so $\psi(n^+)$ holds.

name: A non-empty subset of the natural numbers has a least element
statement: Any non-empty subset of $\mathbb N$ has a least element

name: Definition by recursion on the natural numbers
statement: Let $X$ be a set, $x_0\in X$ and $g:X\rightarrow X$ a function. Then there exists a unique function $f:\omega\rightarrow X$ with $f(0)=x_0$ and $f(n^+)=g(f(n))$ for all $n\in\omega$.

proofs.text:
For $n\in\omega$, a function $h:n\rightarrow X$ will be called $n$-nice if $n=0$ or, if $0\in n$, $h(0)=x_0$ and $h(m^+)=g(h(m))$ for all $m$ with $m^+\in n$.\\
A function $h:\omega\rightarrow X$ will be called very-nice if for each $n\in\omega$, then restriction of $h$ to $n$ is $n$-nice.\\
\\
Therefore restate the conclusion of the theorem as "there exists a very nice function".\\
\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim 1}}: & For each $n\in\omega$ there exists an $n$-nice function.\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & By induction, for $n=0$ there is nothing to prove.\newline
Suppose true for $n$, if $n=0$ we set $h(0)=x_0$ to define a $1$-nice function.\newline
If $n\neq0$ then $n=k^+$ and there exists $h$ which is $n$-nice, we set\break $h'=h\cup\{\langle k^+,g(h(k))\rangle\}$ to define an $n^+$-nice function.
\end{tabular}
\vspace{3mm}\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim 2}}: & Suppose $h_1$ is $n_1$-nice and $h_2$ is $n_2$-nice, then $m\in n_1\cap n_2\Rightarrow h_1(m)=h_2(m)$\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & By induction on $m$. For $m=0$, holds because $0\in n_1\cap n_2\Rightarrow h_1(0)=x_0=h_2(0)$\newline
Suppose true for $m$ and that $m^+\in n_1\cap n_2$, then $h_1(m^+)=g(h_1(m))=g(h_2(m))=h_2(m^+)$, so holds for $m^+$
\end{tabular}
\vspace{3mm}\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim 3}}: & For each $n$ there is a unique $n$-nice function.\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & If $h_1$, $h_2$ are both $n$-nice, then $\forall m\in n_1\cap n_2=n$, $h_1(m)=h_2(m)$, hence $h_1=h_2$.
\end{tabular}
\vspace{3mm}\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim 4}}: & A very-nice function, if it exists, is unique.\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & Suppose $f_1,\ f_2:\omega\rightarrow X$ are very nice. For any $n$, the restrictions of $f_1,f_2$ to $n$ are $n$-nice and hence identical up to $n$. Hence $f_1=f_2$.
\end{tabular}
\vspace{3mm}\\
Note that an $n$-nice function is an element of $\mathcal P(\omega\times X)$ and inside this we can comprehend the subset $N$ of functions which are $n$-nice for some $n$.\\
This $N$ is a set of functions, ie: a set of sets of ordered pairs. Let $f=\bigcup N$, which is now a set of ordered pairs.\\
\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim 5}}: & $f$ is a very-nice function\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & First show that $f$ is a function. Let $n\in\omega$, we know an $n^+$-nice function $h$ exists, and $n\in n^+$ so some pair $\langle n,x\rangle\in f$ exists where $x=h(n)$. If $\langle n,x'\rangle\in f$ then there is a $k$-nice function $h'$ with $n\in k$ and $h'(n)=x'$. By claim 2, $x'=h'(n)=h(n)=x$. So $f$ is indeed a function $\omega\rightarrow X$.\newline
\newline
Finally, show that $f$ is very-nice. Let $n\in\omega$, $h:n^{++}\rightarrow X$ be $n^{++}$-nice. We have $h(0)=x_0$ so $f(0)=x_0$, and $f(n^+)=h(n^+)=g(h(n))=g(f(n))$. So $f$ is very-nice.
\end{tabular}
\vspace{3mm}\\
Thus a very-nice function exists and it is unique.

name: Definition by recursion on two variables
statement: Suppose $A,X$ are sets, $h:A\rightarrow X$ is a function and $g:A\times X\rightarrow X$. Then there exists a unique function $f:A\times\omega\rightarrow X$ with $f(a,0)=h(a)$ for all $a\in A$ and $f(a,n^+)=g(a,f(a,n))$ for all $a\in A$ and $n\in\omega$.

proofs.text:
For each $a\in A$, apply the theorem with $x_0=h(a)$ and $g_a:X\rightarrow X$ given by $g_a(x)=g(a,x)$ to get a unique function $f_a:\omega\rightarrow X$ with $f_a(0)=h(a)$, $f_a(n^+)=g_a(f_a(n))$ for all $n\in\omega$.\\
Now define $f:A\times\omega\rightarrow X$ by $f(a,n)=f_a(n)$.

name: Arithmetic on the natural numbers
Standard arithmetic properties
statement:
For all $n,m,k\in\omega$
\begin{enumerate}
\item $(n+m)+k=n+(m+k)$
\item $n+k=k+n$
\item $n\cdot(m+k)=n\cdot m+n\cdot k$
\item $(n\cdot m)\cdot k=n\cdot(m\cdot k)$
\item $n\cdot k=k\cdot n$
\item $m^{n+k}=m^n\cdot m^k$
\item $m^{n\cdot k}=(m^n)^k$
\end{enumerate}

name: Peano arithmetic
statement:
For $\mathbb N$, $0$, $x\mapsto x^+$, $+$, $\cdot$
\begin{enumerate}
\item The function $x\mapsto x^+$ is injective and its range is every non-zero natural number
\item For all $x$, $x+0=x$
\item For all $x,y$, $x+y^+=(x+y)^+$
\item For all $x$, $x\cdot 0=0$
\item For all $x,y$, $x\cdot y^+=x\cdot y+x$
\item Let $A$ be any subset of $\mathbb N$ with $0\in A$ and for all $x$, if $x\in A$ then $x^+\in A$, then $A=\mathbb N$.
\end{enumerate}

name: The natural numbers form a peano arithmetic
statement: The set $\omega$ with $+,\cdot$ satisfies the axioms of Peano arithmetic,

proofs.text: We're already proved all of this.

name: There is only one Peano arithmetic
statement: If $M,N$ are sets with suitable operations which both satisfy the Peano axioms, then they are isomorphic.

proofs.text: It suffices to show $N$ is isomorphic to $\omega$.

name: Class function
statement: A formula $\phi(x,y)$, maybe with other free variables, is called a class function if for all $x$, there exists a unique $y$ such that $\phi(x,y)$ holds.

name: ZF9 - Replacement
statement: If $\phi(x,y)$ is a class function and $X$ is a set, then the collection $Y$ of sets $y$ such that $\phi(x,y)$ holds for some $x\in X$, is a set.

name: Recursion on the natural numbers, class form
statement: Let $x_0$ be a set and $\phi(x,y)$ a class function. There is a set $Y$ and a unique function $f:\omega\rightarrow Y$ with $f(0)=x_0$ and $\phi(f(n),f(n^+))$ for all $n\in\omega$.

name: How to use class recursion
statement: There exists a set $X=\{\omega,\mathcal P(\omega),\mathcal P(\mathcal P(\omega)),...,\mathcal P^{[i]}(\omega),...\}$

proofs.text:
Let $\phi(x, y)$ be the class function $y=\mathcal P(x)$, $x_0=\omega$.\\
Apply class recursion on $\omega$, this gives a set $Y$ and a function $f:\omega\rightarrow Y$ with $f(0)=\omega$ and $f(n^+)=\mathcal P(f(n))$. Then $X=\{y\in Y:\exists n\in\omega,\ f(n)=y\}$

name: ZF9 - Foundation
statement:
Every non-empty set has an $\epsilon$-minimal element.\\
\\
or: if $x\neq\emptyset$, $\exists y\in x$ s.t. $\forall z\in x$, $z\not\in y$\\
or: if $x\neq\emptyset$, $\exists y\in x$ s.t. $y\cap x=\emptyset$

name: A set cannot be an element of itself
statement: Let $x$ be a set, then $x\not\in x$

proofs.text: Suppose $x\in x$, put $X=\{x\}$, then $X$ validates foundation.

name: Sequence
statement: A sequence in a set $X$ is a function $f:\omega\rightarrow X$

name: There cannot be an infinite sequence of set inclusion
statement: There is no sequence of sets $\{a_0,a_1,a_2,...\}$ s.t. $a_i\in a_{i+1}$ for all $i$.

name: Cardinality
statement:
Let $X,Y$ be sets, we say that $X$ and $Y$ have the same cardinality (or are equinumerous) if there exists a bijection between them. Write $|X|=|Y|$ or $\#X=\#Y$ or $X\sim Y$.\\
\\
We say $X$ has cardinality less than or equal to $Y$ if there exists an injective map $X\rightarrow Y$. Write $X\preceq Y$ or $|X|\leq|Y|$ or $\#X\leq\#Y$.\\
\\
If $X\preceq Y$ but not $X\sim Y$ we say $X$ has cardinality less than $Y$. Write $X\prec Y$ or $|X|<|Y|$ or $\#X<\#Y$.

name: Being equinumerous has the properties of an equivalence relation
statement:
If $A,B,C$ are sets, then $A\sim A$, $A\sim B\Rightarrow B\sim A$ and $A\sim B\land B\sim C\Rightarrow A\sim C$.\\
However, note that $\sim$ is not technically an equivalence relation as it acts on all sets.

proofs.text: Trivial properties of bijections.

name: Simple properties of cardinality
Cantor / Schroder-Bernstein
statement: If $X\preceq Y$ and $Y\preceq X$ then $X\sim Y$.

proofs.text:
We have injective maps $f:X\rightarrow Y$ and $g:Y\rightarrow X$. We want a bijection $h:X\rightarrow Y$ using $f$ on some elements and $g$ on others.\\
\\
We need subsets $Z\subset X$, $W\subset Y$ with the following properties:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $f[Z]=Y-W$, $f|_Z$ is a bijection with $Y-W$
\item $g[W]=X-Z$, $g_W$ is a bijection with $X-Z$
\end{enumerate}
Now, $h:X\rightarrow Y$ with $h(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}f(x)&x\in Z\\g^{-1}(x)&x\in X-Z\end{array}\right.$ would be a bijection.\\
\\
What we need is $Z\subset X$, $Z=X-g[Y-f[Z]]$, then $Z$ and $W=Y-f[Z]$ have the required properties.
$$\begin{array}{rl}f[Z]=Y-(Y-f[Z])=Y-W&\Rightarrow(i)\\Z=X-g[W]\Rightarrow g[W]=X-Z&\Rightarrow(ii)\end{array}$$
Define $H:\mathcal P(X)\rightarrow\mathcal P(Y)$ by $H(A)=A-g[Y-f[A]]$, we want a fixed point $Z$. So we check that $A\subset B\Rightarrow H(A)\subset H(B)$ and use Tarski's fixed-point theorem.\\
\\
So suppose $A\subset B\subset X$, then $Y-f[B]\subset Y-f[A]$ as $f[A]\subset f[B]$. Therefore $g[Y-f[B]]\subset g[Y-f[A]]$ and $H(A)=X-g[Y-f[A]]\subset X-g[Y-f[B]]=H(B)$.

name: Tarski's fixed-point theorem
statement: Suppose $X$ is a set and $H:\mathcal P(X)\rightarrow\mathcal P(X)$ with the property that $H(A)\subset H(B)$ whenever $A\subset B$. Then there exists $C\in\mathcal P(X)$ with $H(C)=C$.

proofs.text:
Call a set expansive if $A\subset H(A)$\\
\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim}}: & If $\mathcal A$ is a set of expansive sets, then $\bigcup\mathcal A$ is expansive\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & If $a\in\bigcup\mathcal A$ then there is $A\in\mathcal A$ with $a\in A$, so $a\in A\subset H(A)$. But $A\subset\bigcup A$ so $H(A)\subset H(\bigcup\mathcal A)$, so $\bigcup A\subset H(\bigcup A)$
\end{tabular}
\vspace{3mm}\\
Then the union of all expansive sets $C=\bigcup\{A\in\mathcal P(X):A\subset H(A)\}$ is fixed.\\
By claim, $C$ is expansive, hence $C\subset H(C)$ and $H(C)\subset H(H(C))$, so $H(C)$ is also expansive. Therefore $H(C)\subset C$, so $C=H(C)$.

name: Cardinality n
statement:
Suppose $X$ is a set and $n\in\omega$. We say that $X$ has cardinality $n$ if $X\sim n$. Write $|X|=n$.\\
We say that $X$ is a finite set if $X\sim n$ for some $n\in\omega$, otherwise $X$ is infinite.

name: An injection on a finite set is surjective
statement: Let $X$ be a finite set, if $f:X\rightarrow X$ is injective, then it is surjective.

name: No two distinct natural numbers have the same cardinality
statement: If $n,m\in\omega$ and $n\neq m$, then $n\not\sim m$

proofs.text: We can suppose $m<n$, let $f:n\rightarrow m$ be a bijection, then considered as a map $f:n\rightarrow n$ it is injective but not surjective as $m+1$ is missed. This is a contradiction.

name: Natural number lesser cardinality criterion
statement: Let $n,m\in\omega$, then $n\preceq m$ iff $n\leq m$

proofs.text:
$n\leq m\Rightarrow n\subset m\Rightarrow n\preceq m$\\
$n\preceq m\land m<n\Rightarrow m\preceq n\Rightarrow n\sim m$ which is a contradiction as $m\neq n$.

name: A subset of a finite set is finite
statement: A subset of a finite set is finite.

name: Countably infinite
statement:
A set $X$ with $X\sim\omega$ is called countably infinite. Write $|X|=\aleph_0$\\
A set is called countable if it is finite or countably infinite.

name: A subset of the natural numbers is countable
statement: If $X\subset\omega$, then $X$ is countable.

proofs.text:
Suppose $X$ is not finite and define $g:\omega\rightarrow\omega$ by $g(n)=\min\{x\in X:n<x\}$\\
Then $g$ is always defined as otherwise for some $n$, $X\subset n$ which would make $X$ finite.\\
Now et $x_0$ be the least element of $X$ and define $f:\omega\rightarrow X$ by $f(0)=x_0$, $f(n^+)=g(f(n))$.\\
Then $f$ is surjective, otherwise letting $a\not\in Range(f)$, by induction $f(n)<a$ for all $n\in\omega$, but again by induction $f(n)\geq n$ which is a contradiction.\\
Therefore $f:\omega\rightarrow X$ is a bijection.

name: Countable criterion by cardinality
statement: $X$ is countable iff $X\preceq\omega$

name: Countable criterion by surjective maps
statement: A non-empty set if countable iff there exists a surjective map $\omega\rightarrow X$

name: Cardinal number
statement:
A cardinal number is the cardinality $|X|$ of some set $X$. For $n\in\omega$, set $|n|=n$, this makes up the finite cardinals.\\
\\
Suppose $a,b$ are cardinal numbers, $a=|A|,b=|B|$, where $A,B$ are disjoint sets. Then:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $a+b$ is cardinality of $A\cup B$
\item $a\cdot b$ is cardinality of $A\times B$
\item $a^b$ is cardinality of $A^B$
\end{enumerate}

name: Properties of cardinal number arithmetic
statement:
Suppose $x,y,z$ are cardinal numbers, then
\begin{enumerate}
\item $x+y=y+x$
\item $x+(y+z)=(x+y)+z$
\item $x+0=x$
\item $x\cdot y=y\cdot x$
\item $x\cdot(y\cdot z)=(x\cdot y)\cdot z$
\item $x\cdot 1=x$
\item $x\cdot(y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z)$
\item $x^{y+z}=x^y\cdot x^z$
\item $x^{y\cdot z}=(x^y)^z$
\item $(x\cdot y)^z=x^z\cdot y^z$
\item These operators agree on finite cardinalities with previously defined arithmetic operators.
\end{enumerate}

name: Arithmetic and inequalities
Cardinality of powerset
statement: For any set $X$, $2^X\sim\mathcal P(X)$

proofs.text:
Define $\Phi:2^X\rightarrow\mathcal P(X)$ by: $\Phi(f)=\{x\in X:f(x)=1\}$ where $f:X\rightarrow2$.\\
\\
This has an inverse. For $Y\subset X$ define $f_Y:X\rightarrow2$ by $f_Y(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}1&x\in Y\\0&x\not\in Y\end{array}\right.$.\\
Then $\Phi(f_Y)=Y$.

name: Cantor's theorem
statement: For any set $X$, there does not exists a surjective map $X\rightarrow\mathcal P(X)$

proofs.text:
True if $X=\emptyset$, so suppose $X
eq\emptyset$.\
Let $f:Xightarrow\mathcal P(X)$ be a function, we shall show that $Range(f)
eq\mathcal P(X)$.\
By comprehension, the "diagonal" $D=\{x\in X:x
ot\in f(x)\}$ is a set, so $D\in\mathcal P(X)$. But if $a\in X$ then $D
eq f(a)$ since $a\in D$ iff $a
ot\in f(a)$. Hence $D(a)
ot\in Range(f)$.

name: Any k < 2^k
statement: For any cardinal number $k$, $k<2^k$.

proofs.text:
Show $k\leq2^k$ by an injection $X\rightarrow\mathcal P(X)$, $k=|X|$, map $x\in X$ to $\{x\}\in\mathcal P(X)$.\\
But by Cantor's theorem cannot have $k\sim2^k$, so $k<2^k$.

name: There are infinitely many infinities
statement: $\aleph_0<2^{\aleph_0}<2^{2^{\aleph_0}}<...$ Therefore there are infinitely many different infinite cardinals.

name: Size of product set of natural numbers
statement:
$\aleph_0\times\aleph_0=\aleph_0$\\
$\Rightarrow|\mathbb Q|=\aleph_0$\\
$\Rightarrow\aleph_0^n=\aleph_0$ for all $n$

name: The power of the continuum
statement: $|\mathbb R|=2^{\aleph_0}$

proofs.text:
First, show: $2^{\aleph_0}\leq|\mathbb R|$ by injection $\Phi:2^\omega\to\mathbb R$, $\Phi(f)=\sum_{n=0}^\infty{f(n)\over3^n}$ where $f:\omega\to2$\\
\\
Next, show: $|\mathbb R|\leq2^{\aleph_0}$ by injection $\Psi:\mathbb R\to\mathcal P(\mathbb Q)$, $\Psi(x)=\{q\in\mathbb Q:q<x\}$.\\
\\
Then, $2^\omega\preceq\mathbb R\preceq\mathcal P(\mathbb Q)\sim\mathcal P(\omega)\sim2^\omega$, therefore $2^{\aleph_0}=|\mathbb R|$

name: Well order
statement: A well-order on a set $X$ is a strict total order $<$ s.t. every non-empty subset $S\subseteq X$ has a least element.

name: A strict total order of a finite set is a well order
statement: A strict total order of a finite set is a well-order.

name: There is no uncountable well-ordered subset of the reals
statement: Any subset of $\mathbb R$ that is well-ordered by $<$ is countable.

name: Strong induction on a well-order
statement:
Let $<$ be a well-order on a set $X$. Suppose $\phi(x)$ is a formula with the property:\\
$$\forall x\in X(\forall y\in X(y<x\rightarrow\phi(y))\rightarrow\phi(x))$$
Then $\phi(x)$ holds for all $x\in X$

proofs.text: Let $S=\{x\in X:\lnot\phi(x)\}$. If $S\neq\emptyset$ then it has a least element $s$. So $\forall y\in X$ with $y<s$, $\phi(y)$ holds, hence $\phi(s)$ holds. This is a contradiction, hence $S=\emptyset$.

name: Order embedding
statement:
Let $X,Y$ sets with strict total orders, an order embedding is a function $f:X\to Y$ s.t.
$$\forall u,v\in X(u<v\to f(u)<f(v))$$
An order-embedding $f:X\to Y$ is called an order isomorphism if $f$ is a bijection.

name: Order embedding properties
Initial segment
statement:
Let $(X,<)$ be a well-ordered set,\\
an initial segment of $X$ is a subset $Z\subseteq X$ s.t. $(z\in Z\land w\in z)\rightarrow w\in Z$\\
\\
For $x\in X$, define the segment in $X$ up to $x$ to be $\{z\in X:z<x\}=seg_X(x)$

name: Initial segment properties
Upper bound
statement:
If $X$ is a well-ordered set and $Z\subseteq X$, then say $x$ is an upper bound for $Z$ if $z<x$ for all $z\in Z$.\\
If $Z$ has an upper bound, say $Z$ is bounded above in $X$.\\
If $Z$ is bounded above, then the set of upper bounds has a least element, call this the supremum, denoted $\sup_X(Z)$.

name: There always exists an embedding between well-ordered sets

proofs.text:
Recall that $\sup(X)$ is the least strict upper bound of $X$.\\
\\
Call an order embedding from and initial segment of $X$ onto an initial segment of $Y$ a "good" function.\\
\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim 1}}: & If $f$ is a good function, then for all $x\in Dom(f)$, $f(x)=\sup\{f(y):y<x\}$\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & Let $t=\sup\{f(y):y<x\}$\newline
Since $f$ is an order embedding, $f(y)<f(x)$ whenever $y<x$, therefore $t\leq f(x)$.\newline
Suppose $t<f(x)$, then $t=f(y)$ for some $y<x$ as $f$ maps onto an initial segment of $Y$. This is a contradiction.\newline
Therefore $f(x)=t$.
\end{tabular}\\
\vspace{3mm}\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim 2}}: & For well-ordered sets $X,Y$ there is at most one good function from $X$ to $Y$\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & Suppose $f,g$ are good functions from $X$ onto initial segments of $Y$ with $f\neq g$. Then $\exists x\in S=\{x\in X:f(x)\neq g(x)\}$. But then ${f(x)=\sup\{f(y):y<x\}=\sup\{g(y):y<x\}=g(x)}$ which is a contradiction.
\end{tabular}\\
\vspace{3mm}\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim 3}}: & The restriction of a good function to an initial segment of its domain is a good function.\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & Let $Z$ be the initial segment to which we restrict $f$. Such a map is an order embedding. Suppose $x\in Z$ and $y\in Y$ with $y<f(x)$. Then $y=f(z)$ for some $z\in Dom(f)$ and $z<x$ so $z\in Z$.
\end{tabular}\\
\vspace{3mm}\\
Define $C$ to be the set $x\in X$ such that there exists a good function from $\{y\in X:y\leq x\}$ to $Y$.\\
\\
If $x\in C$ and $y<x$ and $f:\{z\in X:z\leq x\}\to Y$ is good, then the restriction of $f$ to $\{z\in X:z\leq y\}$ is also good by claim 3. Hence $y\in C$, so $C$ is an initial segment.\\
\\
For each $x\in C$, denote by $f_x$ the unique good function $f_x:\{z\in X:z\leq x\}\to Y$. Then $f_x(z)=f_y(z)$ whenever $z\leq x\leq y$. Define for $x\in C$, $f(x)=f_x(x)$. So if $x,y\in C$ with $x<y$, then $f(x)=f_x(x)=f_y(x)<f_y(y)=f(y)$. So $f$ is an order embedding.\\
\\
Further, if $x\in C$ and $t<f(x)$, then $t<f_x(x)$ so $\exists y\in X$ with $y<x$ such that $t=f_x(y)=f_y(y)=f(y)$. Therefore $f$ is a good function from $C$ to $Y$.\\
\\
If $C=X$ then we have proved (i) of the theorem, so suppose $C\neq X$. Let $t=\sup C$, $D=f[C]$. If $D=Y$ then we have proved (ii) of the theorem as the inverse of $f$ is a good function from $Y$ to $C$. So suppose $D\neq Y$ and let $u=\sup D$. By setting $\bar f(t)=u$ this extends $f$ to a good function $\{z\in X:z\leq t\}$ which contradicts $t\not\in C$.

name: Good function in two directions implies they are bijections
statement: Let $X,Y$ be well-ordered sets. Using the definition of "good" function from the previous theorem, if there are good functions $f:X\to Y$ and $g:Y\to X$ then both are onto and are inverses of each other.

proofs.text: Let $W= Range(f)$, so $W$ is an initial segment of $Y$. Then $f^{-1}$ is a good function from $W$ onto $X$. But $g|_{_W}$ is a good function into $X$, implies $f^{-1}=g|_{_W}$ on $W$. Since $g$ is injective, must have $W=Y$.

name: Good function relation on well-ordered sets
Ordinal number
statement:
A set $\alpha$ is an ordinal number if it is transitive and well-ordered by $\in$\\
\\
Being an ordinal can be expressed as a formula, so ordinal number form a class $\mathbb{ON}$.

name: Properties of ordinal numbers
statement:
Let $\alpha,\beta$ be ordinals
\begin{enumerate}
\item An element of an ordinal is an ordinal.
\item An ordinal is equal to the set of all smaller (under $\in$) ordinals.
\item A transitive proper subset $y\subset\alpha$ is equal to the least element of $\alpha-y$ and so is an ordinal.
\item either $\alpha\subseteq\beta$ or $\beta\subseteq\alpha$
\item $\alpha\subseteq\beta$ iff $\alpha=\beta$ or $\alpha\in\beta$
\item $\alpha\in\beta$ or $\alpha=\beta$ or $\beta\in\alpha$
\end{enumerate}

proofs.text:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Suppose $x\in y\in z\in\alpha$, then by transitivity $y\in\alpha$ and $x\in\alpha$. Because $\in$ is a strict total order on $\alpha$, it is transitive, so $x\in z$. Thus the set $z$ is transitive. By restriction there is a well-ordering of $z$. Hence $z$ is an ordinal.
\item $\alpha=\{\beta:\beta\in\alpha\}=\{\beta\in\mathbb{ON}:\beta\in\alpha\}$ using part (1)
\item Let $u$ be the least element of $\alpha-y$, we show that $y=u$.\\
Since $u$ is least, if $x\in u$ then $x\in y$, so $u\subseteq y$. Suppose $x\in y$, then $x\in\alpha$, so either $x=u$ or $u\in x$, which lead to contradictions, or $x\in u$ which implies $y\subseteq u$. Hence $y=u$
\item Suppose neither holds, then $y=\alpha\cap\beta$ is a transitive proper subset of both $\alpha$ and $\beta$, so $y=\gamma$ is the least element of $\alpha-y$ and $y=\delta$ is the least element of $\beta-y$. Hence $\gamma=\delta\in y$ which is a contradiction.
\item $(\Leftarrow)$ If $\alpha=\beta$ then $\alpha\subseteq\beta$ and if $\alpha\in\beta$ then $\alpha\subseteq\beta$ by transitivity.\\
$(\Rightarrow)$ If $\alpha\subseteq\beta$ but $\alpha\neq\beta$, then $\alpha$ is a transitive proper subset of $\beta$, so $\alpha$ is the least element of $\beta-\alpha$, hence $\alpha\in\beta$.
\item By (iv) and (v)
\end{enumerate}

name: Constructing ordinals

proofs.text:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Conditions hold vacuously
\item let $\alpha\in\mathbb{ON}$, $\alpha^+$ is transitive by previous work and $\in$ is a strict total order on $\alpha^+$\\
Suppose $S\subseteq\alpha^+$ is non-empty. If $S\cap\alpha\neq\emptyset$, then $S\cap\alpha$ has a least element $\beta\in\alpha$ as $\alpha$ is well-ordered, then $\beta$ is least in $S$ as the only other element is $\alpha$. If $S\cap\alpha=\emptyset$, then $S=\{\alpha\}$ which has least element $\alpha$.
\item Let $A$ be a set of ordinals and $U=\bigcup A$. We show that $U\in\mathbb{ON}$\\
Let $x\in y\in U$, then $y\in a$ for some $a\in A$, so by transitivity $x\in a$ and so $x\in U$. So $U$ is transitive.\\
Let $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in U$, then $\alpha,\beta,\gamma$ are all ordinals, so $\alpha\not\in\alpha$ and $\alpha\in\beta\in\gamma\Rightarrow\alpha\in\gamma$ and either $\alpha\in\beta$ or $\alpha=\beta$ or $\beta\in\alpha$. So $\in$ is a strict total order on $U$.\\
Let $S\subseteq U$ with $\alpha\in S$. Maybe $\alpha$ is least in $S$, else $S\cap\alpha\neq\emptyset$ and has a least element $\beta\in\alpha$. Then $\beta$ is least in $S$. So $U$ is well-ordered.
\end{enumerate}

name: The natural numbers are a subset of the ordinals
Any well-ordered set is isomorphic to an ordinal
statement: Let $X$ be well-ordered, then there exists a unique ordinal $\alpha$ and order-isomorphism $f:X\to\alpha$

proofs.text:
Assume $X\neq\emptyset$, otherwise $X$ is uniquely order-isomorphic to $\emptyset\in\mathbb{ON}$\\
\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim}}: & $\{\emptyset\}$ is the unique ordinal with one element.\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & $\{\emptyset\}=\emptyset^+\in\mathbb{ON}$. Suppose $x=\{\alpha\}$ is also an ordinal, then $\beta\in\alpha\Rightarrow\beta\in x\Rightarrow\beta=\alpha$ which is a contradiction.
\end{tabular}\\
\vspace{3mm}\\
So we have showed that: for any $\alpha$ there can be only one order-isomorphism of $X$ with $\alpha$.\\
\\\
Let $A$ be the set of $x\in X$ such that for all $t\in X$ with $t\leq x$, $I_t=\{y\in X:y\leq t\}$ has an order-isomorphism onto some unique ordinal $\alpha_t$. Then $A\neq\emptyset$ as if $x\in X$ is least then $\{x\}$ is uniquely order-isomorphic to $\{\emptyset\}$, so $x\in A$. Also $A$ is an initial segment by its definition.\\
\\
By replacement, the union of ranges of $f_x$ for $x\in A$, is a set, call it $\alpha$. Then $\alpha\in\mathbb{ON}$ as a union of ordinals. Define $f$ by $f(x)=f_x(x)$, then $f:A\to\alpha$ is an order-isomorphism.\\
\\
If $g:A\to\beta$ is an order isomorphism with $\beta\in\mathbb{ON}$, then for each $x\in A$, $g|_{_{I_x}}=f_{_{I_x}}$, so $\alpha$ and $f$ are indeed unique.\\
\\
Finally, show $A=X$. If not, let $y=\sup A$ and define $\bar f$ on $A\cup\{y\}$ by $f(y)=\alpha$. Then $\bar f$ is an order-isomorphism and unique, so $y\in A$ which is a contradiction.

name: Ordinals are isomorphic iff they are equal
statement: Ordinals $\alpha,\beta$ is order-isomorphic iff $\alpha=\beta$.

proofs.text:
$(\Leftarrow)$ Trivial isomorphism by the identity map.\\
$(\Rightarrow)$ There exists a unique ordinal $\gamma$ order-isomorphic to $\alpha$, either $\gamma=\beta$ so we have the conclusion or $\gamma\neq\beta$ so $\alpha\neq\beta$.

name: Types of ordinal
statement:
An ordinal $\alpha$ is called a successor ordinal if $\alpha=\beta^+$ for some $\beta\in\mathbb{ON}$\\
An ordinal $\alpha$ which is not $0$ or a successor is called a limit ordinal
