name: Limit ordinal criterion
statement: An ordinal $\lambda$ is a limit ordinal iff $\lambda\neq0$ and $\forall\alpha\in\lambda$, $\alpha^+\in\lambda$

proofs.text:

eq\lambda$, so $\alpha^+<\lambda$, so $\alpha^+\in\lambda$.
\item[$(\Leftarrow)$ ] Suppose $\lambda
eq0$ and $ orall\alpha\in\lambda$, $\alpha^+\in\lambda$. If $\lambda= eta^+$ then $ eta\in\lambda$ but $ eta^+

name: Supremum of a set of ordinals
Alternate ordinal type criterion
Hartog's theorem
statement: Let $X$ be a set, then there exists an ordinal $\alpha$ with $|\alpha|\not\leq|X|$

name: There exists an uncountable ordinal
statement: There exists an uncountable ordinal.

proofs.text: Apply Hartog's theorem to $\omega$

name: A non-empty class of ordinals has a least element
statement: Let $\phi(x)$ be a formula such that $\phi(\alpha)$ holds for some $\alpha\in\mathbb{ON}$, then there is a least ordinal $\beta$ for which $\phi(\beta)$ holds.

proofs.text: Maybe $\alpha$ is least for which $\phi(\alpha)$ holds. Otherwise, $\phi(x)$ holds for some $x\in\alpha$, so $\{\gamma\in\alpha:\phi(\gamma)\text{ holds}\}\neq\emptyset$. This has a least element $\beta$ as $\alpha$ is well-ordered by $\in$. Then $\beta$ is the least ordinal such that $\phi(\beta)$ holds. Suppose $\phi(\delta)$ holds for $\delta\in\mathbb{ON}$, either $\alpha\leq\delta$ or $\delta<\alpha$, hence $\beta\leq\delta$.

name: Strong transfinite induction
statement:
Suppose $\phi(x)$ is a formula such that $\forall\alpha\in\mathbb{ON},\ (((\beta\in\mathbb{ON}\land\beta<\alpha)\to\phi(\beta))\to\phi(\alpha))$.\\
Then $\phi(\alpha)$ holds for all $\alpha\in\mathbb{ON}$.

proofs.text: Note that $\phi(0)$ holds vacuously. Suppose $\lnot\phi(\alpha)$ holds for some ordinal $\alpha$, then it must have a least failure $\beta$. But then $\forall\gamma<\beta$, $\phi(\gamma)$ holds, so $\phi(\beta)$ holds which is a contradiction.

name: Transfinite recursion on the ordinals
Improved transfinite recursion on the ordinals
Ordinal arithmetic
statement:
Define ordinal addition and multiplication by class function $+,\cdot:\mathbb{ON}\times\mathbb{ON}\to\mathbb{ON}$\\
\\
For all $\alpha\in\mathbb{ON}$
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\alpha+0=\alpha$
\item $\alpha+\beta^+=(\alpha+\beta)^+$ for all $\beta$ a successor ordinal
\item $\alpha+\lambda=\bigcup_{\beta<\lambda}(\alpha+\beta)$ for $\lambda$ a limit ordinal
\item $\alpha\cdot0=0$
\item $\alpha\cdot\beta^+=\alpha\cdot\beta+\alpha$ for $\beta$ a successor ordinal
\item $\alpha\cdot\lambda=\bigcup_{\beta<\lambda}(\alpha\cdot\beta)$ for $\lambda$ a limit ordinal
\end{enumerate}

name: Examples of ordinal arithmetic
statement:
Note that ordinal arithmetic and cardinal arithmetic agree on $\omega$, but otherwise they can differ.
\begin{enumerate}
\item $1+\omega=\bigcup_{n\in\omega}(1+n)=\bigcup_{n\in\omega}(n+1)=\bigcup_{n\in\omega}n^+=\omega$
\item $\omega+1=\omega+0^+=(\omega+0)^+=\omega^+=\omega\cup\{\omega\}\neq\omega$
\item $2\cdot\omega=\bigcup_{n\in\omega}(2\cdot n)=\omega$
\item $\omega\cdot2=\omega\cdot1+\omega=\omega+\omega\neq\omega$
\end{enumerate}

name: Ordinal addition is strictly monotonic in the second argument
statement:
Ordinal arithmetic is strictly monotonic in the second argument, ie:
$$\forall\alpha,\beta,\beta',\ \beta<\beta'\Rightarrow\alpha+\beta<\alpha+\beta'$$

name: Ordinal addition is weakly increasing in first argument
statement: $\forall\alpha,\beta\in\mathbb{ON},\ \alpha+\beta\geq\beta$

name: Ordinal addition is surjective
statement: Suppose $\alpha\leq\beta$, then there exist $\gamma$ with $\alpha+\gamma=\beta$

name: Sum of orders
statement:
For ordinals $X,Y$ where $X$ has order-type $\alpha$, $Y$ has order-type $\beta$ and $X\cap Y=\emptyset$, the sum $\alpha+\beta$ can be defined as the order-type on $X\cup Y$ defined by: "elements of $X$ precede elements of $Y$, inside $X$ and $Y$ use the given orders $\alpha,\beta$"\\
\\
Call this the sum of orders on $X$ and $Y$.

name: The sum order is the order type of the sum
statement: Let $X,Y$ be disjoint sets, let $\alpha,\beta\in\mathbb{ON}$. Suppose $(X,<_X)$ has order-type $\alpha$ and $(Y,<_Y)$ has order-type $\beta$. Then $X\cup Y$ with sum-order has order-type $\alpha+\beta$.

name: Ordinal addition is associative
statement: Ordinal addition is associative

proofs.text: Let $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{ON}$, say $X,Y,Z$ are disjoint sets of order-types $\alpha,\beta,\gamma$ respectively. Then $X\cup(Y\cup Z)$ and $(X\cup Y)\cup Z$ with "sums" are the same order-type (as the identity map is an order isomorphism). Hence $\alpha+(\beta+\gamma)=(\alpha+\beta)+\gamma$.

name: Product of orders
statement: Suppose $(X,<_X)$ has order-type $\alpha$ and $(Y,<_Y)$ has order-type $\beta$. Define the product order on $X\times Y$ to be the reverse lexicographic order, ie: $(x,y)<(x',y')$ if $y<y'$ or $y=y'$ and $x<x'$.

name: The product order is the order of the product
statement: The product order on $X\times Y$ is $\alpha\cdot\beta$

proofs.text: By induction on $\beta$ for fixed $\alpha$

name: Ordinal multiplication is associative
statement: Ordinal multiplication is associative

proofs.text: $X\times(Y\times Z)$ and $(X\times Y)\times Z$ are order isomorphic

name: Ordinal distributivity
statement: $\alpha\cdot(\beta+\gamma)=\alpha\cdot\beta+\alpha\cdot\gamma$ for all $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{ON}$

name: Ordinal multiplication is strictly monotonic in the second argument
statement: If $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{ON}$, $\alpha\neq0$ and $\beta<\gamma$, then $\alpha\cdot\beta<\alpha\cdot\gamma$.

name: ZFC10 - Axiom of Choice
statement: Let $X$ be a non-empty set of disjoint sets, then there is a set $B$ which intersects each element of $X$ precisely once.

name: Cardinal Comparability (CC)
statement: If $X,Y$ are sets, then $X\preceq Y$ or $Y\preceq X$

name: Well-ordering Principle
statement: Every set can be well-ordered.

name: Assuming WO, every set is equinumerous with an ordinal
statement: Assume WO, then every set is equinumerous with an ordinal.

proofs.text: Let $X$ be a set, by WO there is a well-order $<$ on $X$. By an earlier theorem, $(X,<)$ is order isomorphic to a unique ordinal $\alpha$. So $X\sim\alpha$.

name: WO implies CC
statement: WO $\Rightarrow$ CC

proofs.text: If $X,Y$ are sets, then there exist ordinals $\alpha,\beta$ such that $X\sim\alpha,Y\sim\beta$. But ordinals are comparable, so either $\alpha<\beta$, $\alpha=\beta$ or $\beta<\alpha$. Hence by composing maps, $\alpha\leq\beta\Rightarrow X\preceq Y$ and $\beta\leq\alpha\Rightarrow Y\preceq X$.

name: CC implies WO
statement: Let $X$ be any set. By Hartogs' theorem, $\exists\alpha\in\mathbb{ON}$ such that $\alpha\not\leq X$, so by CC $X\preceq\alpha$. Define $<$ on $X$ by $x<y$ iff $f(x)<f(y)$ where $f:X\to\alpha$ is an injection. Then $X$ is well-ordered.

name: Choice function
statement: A choice function for a set $X$ is a function $f:\mathcal P(X)\setminus\{\emptyset\}\to X$ such that $\forall A$, $f(A)\in A$.

name: AC iff every set has a choice function
statement: AC is equivalent to the statement: "every set has a choice function".

name: AC implies WO
statement: AC $\Rightarrow$ WO

proofs.text:
Let $X$ be a set and $f:\mathcal P(X)\setminus\{\emptyset\}	o X$ be a choice function on $X$. Let $A$ be a set with $A
ot\in X$, which exists as $X
ot\in X$. By transfinite recursion, define $\mathbb F:\mathbb{ON}	o\mathbb V$ as follows:
$$\mathbb F(\alpha)=\left\{ egin{array}{ll}f(X\setminus\{\mathbb F( eta): eta<\alpha\})&	ext{: if }X\setminus\{\mathbb F( eta): eta<\alpha\}
eq\emptyset\A&	ext{: otherwise}\end{array}ight.$$
Suppose $\mathbb F( eta)
eq A$ for all $ eta\in\alpha$, then $\{( eta,\mathbb F( eta)): eta\in\alpha\}$ is an injective map $\alpha	o X$. By Hartogs' theorem we must have $\mathbb F(\alpha)=A$ for some $\alpha\in\mathbb{ON}$. Let $\alpha$ be the least such ordinal, then $\{( eta,\mathbb F( eta): eta\in\alpha\}$ is a bijection $\alpha	o X$. Use this to define a well-order on $X$.

name: WO implies AC
statement: WO $\Rightarrow$ AC

proofs.text: Let $X$ be a set and $<$ a well-order on $X$. Then the map $f:\mathcal P(X)\setminus\{\emptyset\}\to X$ defined by $f(A)=\min A$ is a choice function for $X$.

name: WO, CC, AC are all equivalent
statement: WO, CC, AC are all equivalent in the presence of the other axioms.

name: Chain / Maximal
Zorn's lemma
statement: Suppose $Z\neq\emptyset$ and that $\bigcup C\in Z$ whenever $C$ is a chain in $Z$, then $Z$ has a maximal element.

proofs.text:
Assume AC and suppose $Z$ is a non-empty set with "the chain condition". Let $<$ be a well-order of $Z$, so $(Z,<)$ is order-isomorphic to some (unique) ordinal $\alpha$ via some (unique) order isomorphism $\pi:\alpha\to Z$.\\
\\
Define $f:\alpha\to\{0,1\}$ by recursion as follows:
$$f(\alpha)=\left\{\begin{array}{lll}1&:&\pi(\beta)\subseteq\pi(\alpha)\text{ for all }\beta<\alpha\text{ with }f(\beta)=1\\0&:&\text{otherwise}\end{array}\right.$$
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim 1}}: & For all $\beta>0$, $\{\pi(\gamma):\gamma<\beta\land f(\gamma)=1\}$ is a chain.\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & If $c_1=\pi(\gamma),c_2=\pi(\delta)$ with (say) $\gamma\leq\delta$, then the definition of $\gamma$ requires $c_1\subseteq c_2$.
\end{tabular}
\vspace{3mm}\\
In particular $C=\{\pi(\gamma):\gamma<\alpha\land f(\gamma)=1\}$ is a chain. Let $Z=\bigcup C\in Z$\\
\\
\begin{tabular}{r p{125mm}}
\textbf{\underline{Claim 1}}: & $Z$ is a maximal element.\\
\textbf{\underline{proof}}: & Suppose $Z\subseteq Z'\in Z$ and $Z'=\pi(\epsilon)$. Let $\gamma<\epsilon$ and $f(\gamma)=1$, then $\pi(\gamma)\in C$ so $\pi(\gamma)\subseteq Z\subseteq Z'$. So $f(\epsilon)=1$, so $Z'\in C$, so $Z'\subseteq Z$, hence $Z=Z'$.
\end{tabular}

name: Every vector space has a basis
statement: Every vector space has a basis.

proofs.text:
Let $V$ be a vector space over a field $K$. The idea is to use Zorn's lemma to get a maximal linearly independent set, this will span $V$ and hence be a basis.\\
\\
Let $Z$ be the set of all linearly independent subsets of $V$. Then $V$ is non-empty as $\emptyset$ is linearly independent.\\

name: Initial ordinal
statement: An infinite ordinal $\alpha$ is called an initial ordinal if it is not equinumerous with any strictly smaller ordinal.

name: Every infinite set is equinumerous with a unique initial ordinal
statement: Every infinite set is equinumerous with a unique initial ordinal

proofs.text:
Let $X$ be an infinite set, then $X$ is equinumerous with some ordinal. Let $\alpha$ be the least ordinal equinumerous with $X$. Then $\alpha$ is an initial ordinal.\\
\\
Now, if $X\sim\beta$ for some other initial ordinal $\beta$, then $\alpha\sim\beta\Rightarrow\alpha=\beta$. So $\alpha$ is unique.

name: The initial ordinals are unbounded
statement: If $\{\beta_\gamma:\gamma\in\alpha\}$ is a set of initial ordinals, then there exists an initial ordinal exceeding them all.

proofs.text: The union $\lambda=\bigcup\{\beta_\gamma:\gamma\in\alpha\}$ is an ordinal which is bigger than all of them. Then $\mathcal P(\lambda)$ is equinumerous with some initial ordinal $\mu$ with $\mu>\lambda>\beta_\gamma$ for all $\gamma\in\alpha$.

statement:

name: There is no set of all ordinal numbers
statement: There is no set of all ordinal numbers.

proofs.text: Suppose $O$ is the set of all ordinal numbers. Then $\alpha=\bigcup O$ is an ordinal and so is $\alpha^+$. Therefore $\alpha\in\alpha^+\in O$, so $\alpha\in\bigcup O=\alpha$ which is a contradiction.

name: There is no set of all cardinal numbers
statement: There is no set of all cardinal numbers.

proofs.text: If there were such a set $C$, then $O=\{\alpha:\omega_\alpha\in C\}$ would be the set of all ordinals.

name: The self product of an infinite set is equinumerous with itself
statement: Suppose $X$ is an infinite set, then $X\times X\sim X$

proofs.text:
Let $Z$ be the set of all bijections $f:Y\times Y\to Y$ where $Y\subseteq X$.\\
\\
Then $Z\neq\emptyset$ as $\aleph_0\leq|X|$ as there exists a bijection $\omega\times\omega\to\omega$. So $X$ contains some countably infinite subset $Y$, also $Z$ has the chain condition. Therefore by Zorn's lemma, $Z$ contains a maximal element $F:Y\times Y\to Y$ where $Y$ is infinite.\\
\\
Suppose $|X\setminus Y|\geq|Y|$, let $W\subset X\setminus Y$ with $W\sim Y$, then $|Y|\leq3|Y|\leq|Y|\cdot|Y|=|Y|$ because of $F$. So we have a bijection $g:(Y\times W)\cup(W\times W)\cup(W\times Y)\to W$. Then $F\cup g:(Y\cup W)\times(Y\cup W)\to(Y\cup W)$ is a bijection, which contradictions $F$ being maximal.\\
\\
So by CC, $|X\setminus Y|<|Y|$, so $|X|=|Y|+|X\setminus Y|\leq2|Y|\leq|Y|^2=|Y|\leq|X|$. Hence we have $X=Y$, so $X\times X\sim X$.
